{"uri": "8235037303", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "13:40:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T13:40:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T13:40:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/joshkatzowitz/2024/07/20/jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-odds-records-prediction/", "title": "Jake Paul Vs. Mike Perry: Odds, Records, Prediction", "body": "While Jake Paul is the best YouTube star to ever lace up a pair of boxing gloves, his opponent on Saturday, Mike Perry, is one of the best bare knuckle boxers to ever, um, not lace up a pair of gloves. What happens when the two face off on Saturday night in their eight-round fight (that features gloves)? The odds say Paul will win, but Perry thinks his bare knuckle experience will lead him to the upset. Here's everything you need to know about Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry, including the odds, their records and a prediction on who will win.\n\nOriginally, Paul was supposed to face Hall of Famer Mike Tyson tonight, but after Tyson recently dealt with ulcer issues, Paul tapped Perry to take his place.\n\nIt's unclear how much of a threat Perry holds to Paul. But Perry has made quite a name for himself in combat sports. He was a decent but not great MMA fighter, but his stock rose when he began fighting for the Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship (BKFC) promotion.\n\nIn the short time that BKFC has existed, Perry is its biggest superstar and perhaps the best fighter in that combat sports niche. How that experience will compare when he faces Paul in an actual boxing match with gloves is unclear. But the 32-year-old Perry is excited to see what happens.\n\n\"I worked so hard for this,\" he told CBS Sports. \"This is not just another day in the office for me. I thrive off of the pressure. I live for this. I have been getting paid millions of bucks fighting people. I have been doing this a long time so this money fight ain't nothing new to me. I need $20 million. I ain't got enough yet. I've got to check that off my box list and get my mansion and my yacht and bring my family on the boat every day.\"\n\nApparently, Tyson is concerned with Paul's chances of winning. If Paul were to lose, how would that affect his new date to meet Tyson in November? It certainly wouldn't help the buildup, and even Paul admits that it could cost him the chance to get Tyson in the ring altogether.\n\n\"(Tyson) was concerned about me taking this fight,\" Paul said, via USA Today. \"He's like, 'What is Jake thinking? This guy Mike Perry is a killer.' So, he had some concerns. But Tyson, my message to you is don't worry. I'm going to put this guy to sleep. This is a Mike appetizer and you're next.\"\n\nEither way, UFC analyst Dan Hardy said Paul should beware.\n\n\"It's a recipe for disaster for Jake Paul,\" Hardy told MMA Fighting. \"I'm really genuinely surprised that he's allowing Mike Perry to punch him, because Mike Perry is going to savor the opportunity . . .\n\n\"Mike Perry's an animal. He's an absolute barbarian, and he is made for striking sports. Anything where he doesn't have to worry about someone trying to hold onto him and take him down and make it a slow night for him, he is perfect . . . Mike Perry is there to eat your face, and you've got to be prepared for that kind of intensity.\"\n\nHere's more info on the Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry showdown that U.S. viewers can watch on PPV.com (no subscription required) for $64.99 beginning at 9 p.m. ET on Saturday.\n\nEven though some in the MMA community think Perry will destroy Paul, the oddsmakers don't share that view. Paul is the -500 betting favorite (bet $500 to win $100), while Perry is the +350 underdog (win $350 on a $100 wager. There's some value in grabbing Paul to win by stoppage at -120, and if recent history is any indication, I wouldn't mind taking Paul to win by KO/TKO in rounds 1-2 at +550. If you like Perry, maybe grab him to win by stoppage at +550.\n\nAfter losing a close split decision to Tommy Fury last year, Paul (9-1, 6 KOs) has won three in a row in the past 11 months. And two of those victories came against professional boxers Andre August and Ryan Bourland, who had a combined 27-3-1 before facing Paul. Paul knocked out both of them in the first round makes the case that, yes, Paul should be a considered a legitimate boxer.\n\nPerry (0-1) has almost no experience as a professional boxer who wears gloves in the ring. In his only fight, he was knocked out by Kenneth McNeil in 2015. But Perry has been successful in bare knuckle boxing, going 5-0 since February 2022. As an MMA fighter, he amassed a 14-8 record.\n\nMy BKFC knowledge is minimal, so I don't have a great feel for how dangerous Perry will be to Paul. But I know what Paul can do against a boxing neophyte -- he basically destroys them. If Perry were a huge threat to Paul, I'm not sure Paul would have picked him as a Tyson replacement. So, I'll go with Paul by stoppage in the second round.", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8234967110", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "12:33:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T12:33:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T12:32:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/boxing/news/jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-fight-predictions-odds-preview-undercard-start-time-expert-picks/", "title": "Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry fight predictions, odds, preview, undercard, start time, expert picks - CBSSports.com", "body": "The showdown is set for Saturday night in Tampa with quite a few implications Most Valuable Promotions\n\nWhen Jake Paul meets Mike Perry on Saturday, he does so with a massively lucrative November clash with Mike Tyson hanging in the balance. At least, that's what Paul has suggested. Whether that's true or not is still to be seen -- and entirely depends on whether Perry can pull the upset.\n\nThere is risk for Paul in taking this fight. to be sure. While Perry washed out of the UFC (after a promising start as a fan-friendly brawler) with a 3-7 record over his final 10 fights in the promotion, he has found new life as the premier star for Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship. Along with finding his way in BKFC, Perry has quell many of the personal demons that seemed to be leading his life in a disastrous direction.\n\nPerry has been able to find success, and a 5-0 record, in BKFC by mauling opponents with ungloved shots that have cut, swelled and otherwise maimed his opponents.\n\nStill, Paul has made quite a boxing career out of fighting former UFC fighters. While he has experimented with facing the occasional \"real boxer,\" defeating a few club fighters and losing a moderately controversial split decision against Tommy Fury, the bulk of Paul's meaningful fights have come against men like Tyron Woodley (twice), Ben Askren, Nate Diaz and Anderson Silva. Having now had years of dedicated boxing training, Paul has outworked and dropped all of those men who have entered on more or less a single dedicated boxing fight camp.\n\n\"To stay getting experience under the bright lights on my world, on my path to world championship. And that's what matters, is getting the experience under the bright lights,\" Paul said at the final press conference. \"And this is a Mike appetizer. Mike warm up, but they're both killers at the end of the day, and I do have to be sharp. He does have one punch knockout power that I do have to respect. But other than that, it's going to be easy.\"\n\nPaul has also taken advantage of being the larger man in those fights. While Paul has fought at the cruiserrweight limit, or at least at catchweights above the 175-pound light heavyweight limit in boxing, all of his former UFC opponents have been career welterweights (170 pounds) and middleweights (185) in the UFC, though Silva had a handful of fights at 205 pounds.\n\nLike those previous opponents, Perry was a welterweight in the UFC and has fought at 175 and 185 pounds in BKFC, being physically undersized at 185, though built perfectly for the bare-knuckle world.\n\n\"I'm doing it for everybody, for me, for the fans, for BKFC, for MMA, you know, just mainly for me, because I believe in myself and my boxing ability,\" Perry said. \"I'm a brawling boxing mug, so I'm ready to get in the ring with Jake and have some fun.\"\n\nPaul will have all the physical advantages heading into the fight, standing three inches taller, with a five-inch reach advantage and a considerable weight advantage for this 200-pound fight. The weight factor is exaggerated in this fight considering Paul had been bulking up to over 200 pounds for a heavyweight fight with Tyson, which was postponed after the 58-year-old Tyson suffered an ulcer flare-up and left Paul scrambling to find a replacement opponent to keep the July 20 date intact.\n\nThe undercard is fairly typical for a crossover boxing event with some former and current champions along with another former UFC fighter looking to make the jump. Undisputed women's featherweight champion Amanda Serrano is in action when she takes on Stevie Morgan in the featured bout. Serrano was also expected to compete on the Tyson card in a rematch with undisputed two-division queen Katie Taylor. But with the postponement, Serrano wanted to stay active with a bout before November, especially after having her fight in March fall through on the day of the fight.\n\nPaul decided to take the risk of taking on Perry, who brings an aggression Paul has not faced yet in his boxing career. Now he has to navigate the choppy waters of an ultra-aggressive opponent who has found a nose for the big moment in recent years.\n\nPaul vs. Perry fight card, oddsJake Paul -425 vs. Mike Perry +300, cruiserweightAmanda Serrano -4000 vs. Stevie Morgan +1500, junior welterweightsAshton Sylve -295 vs. Lucas Bahdi +225, lightweightsShadasia Green -2500 vs. Natasha Spence +1100, super middleweights\n\nJulio Cesar Chavez Jr. -280 vs. Uriah Hall +215, cruiserweight\n\nPrediction\n\nWhile Perry is a legitimately dangerous opponent, it should be kept in mind that Paul and his team have been extremely careful in fight selection. There's clearly a reason Paul feels Perry is a good opponent heading into the Tyson fight. Maybe it's the size difference, maybe it's that they see Perry's reckless face-first fighting style and see an opponent that would be easy to pick apart and blast out with a big right hand. Whatever it is, Paul isn't taking whatever small risk there is of losing out of the Tyson fight by taking on someone he's afraid of fighting.\n\nPerry's power is a bit overstated at this point. The final 10 fights of his MMA career came without Perry scoring a stoppage. Though Perry has three straight TKO wins in BKFC, those have largely been the product of his bare-knuckle punches causing significant facial damage. In his most recent fight, Perry dropped 40-year-old Thiago Alves near the one-minute mark of the opening round and while Alves was able to beat the count, the fight was waived off as the referee didn't deem him fit to continue.\n\nAgainst a much larger man wearing much larger gloves, it's hard to see Perry getting the stoppage. And Perry's style is one that gets him hit as much, if not more, than he hits his opponents. It isn't hard to see Paul safely boxing his way to a decision win, especially with how boxing gloves will temper both Perry's power and allow Paul to block punches that Perry is used to connecting with in bare-knuckle and MMA. Rather than the decision, we're predicting Paul to get the stoppage, finding a good spot to get in with some big power shots as Perry tries to charge forward and apply his aggression. Pick: Jake Paul via TKO6\n\nWho wins Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry, and which prop is a must-back? Visit SportsLine now to see Brandon Wise's best bets for Saturday, all from the CBS combat sports specialist who nailed Jake Paul's first-round KO of Ryan Bourland at +200, and find out.", "source": {"uri": "8233899972", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:10:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:10:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:10:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/boxing/news/jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-fight-predictions-odds-undercard-preview-start-time-expert-picks/", "title": "Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry fight predictions, odds, undercard, preview, start time, expert picks - CBSSports.com", "body": "The showdown is set for Saturday night in Tampa with quite a few implications Most Valuable Promotions\n\nWhen Jake Paul meets Mike Perry on Saturday, he does so with a massively lucrative November clash with Mike Tyson hanging in the balance. At least, that's what Paul has suggested. Whether that's true or not is still to be seen -- and entirely depends on whether Perry can pull the upset.\n\nThere is risk for Paul in taking this fight. to be sure. While Perry washed out of the UFC (after a promising start as a fan-friendly brawler) with a 3-7 record over his final 10 fights in the promotion, he has found new life as the premier star for Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship. Along with finding his way in BKFC, Perry has quell many of the personal demons that seemed to be leading his life in a disastrous direction.\n\nPerry has been able to find success, and a 5-0 record, in BKFC by mauling opponents with ungloved shots that have cut, swelled and otherwise maimed his opponents.\n\nStill, Paul has made quite a boxing career out of fighting former UFC fighters. While he has experimented with facing the occasional \"real boxer,\" defeating a few club fighters and losing a moderately controversial split decision against Tommy Fury, the bulk of Paul's meaningful fights have come against men like Tyron Woodley (twice), Ben Askren, Nate Diaz and Anderson Silva. Having now had years of dedicated boxing training, Paul has outworked and dropped all of those men who have entered on more or less a single dedicated boxing fight camp.\n\nPaul has also taken advantage of being the larger man in those fights. While Paul has fought at the cruiserrweight limit, or at least at catchweights above the 175-pound light heavyweight limit in boxing, all of his former UFC opponents have been career welterweights (170 pounds) and middleweights (185) in the UFC, though Silva had a handful of fights at 205 pounds.\n\nLike those previous opponents, Perry was a welterweight in the UFC and has fought at 175 and 185 pounds in BKFC, being physically undersized at 185, though built perfectly for the bare-knuckle world.\n\nPaul will have all the physical advantages heading into the fight, standing three inches taller, with a five-inch reach advantage and a considerable weight advantage for this 200-pound fight. The weight factor is exaggerated in this fight considering Paul had been bulking up to over 200 pounds for a heavyweight fight with Tyson, which was postponed after the 58-year-old Tyson suffered an ulcer flare-up and left Paul scrambling to find a replacement opponent to keep the July 20 date intact.\n\nPaul decided to take the risk of taking on Perry, who brings an aggression Paul has not faced yet in his boxing career. Now he has to navigate the choppy waters of an ultra-aggressive opponent who has found a nose for the big moment in recent years.\n\nPaul vs. Perry fight card, oddsJake Paul -425 vs. Mike Perry +300, cruiserweightAmanda Serrano -4000 vs. Stevie Morgan +1500, junior welterweightsAshton Sylve -295 vs. Lucas Bahdi +225, lightweightsShadasia Green -2500 vs. Natasha Spence +1100, super middleweights\n\nJulio Cesar Chavez Jr. -280 vs. Uriah Hall +215, cruiserweight\n\nPrediction\n\nWhile Perry is a legitimately dangerous opponent, it should be kept in mind that Paul and his team have been extremely careful in fight selection. There's clearly a reason Paul feels Perry is a good opponent heading into the Tyson fight. Maybe it's the size difference, maybe it's that they see Perry's reckless face-first fighting style and see an opponent that would be easy to pick apart and blast out with a big right hand. Whatever it is, Paul isn't taking whatever small risk there is of losing out of the Tyson fight by taking on someone he's afraid of fighting.\n\nPerry's power is a bit overstated at this point. The final 10 fights of his MMA career came without Perry scoring a stoppage. Though Perry has three straight TKO wins in BKFC, those have largely been the product of his bare-knuckle punches causing significant facial damage. In his most recent fight, Perry dropped 40-year-old Thiago Alves near the one-minute mark of the opening round and while Alves was able to beat the count, the fight was waived off as the referee didn't deem him fit to continue.\n\nAgainst a much larger man wearing much larger gloves, it's hard to see Perry getting the stoppage. And Perry's style is one that gets him hit as much, if not more, than he hits his opponents. It isn't hard to see Paul safely boxing his way to a decision win, especially with how boxing gloves will temper both Perry's power and allow Paul to block punches that Perry is used to connecting with in bare-knuckle and MMA. Rather than the decision, we're predicting Paul to get the stoppage, finding a good spot to get in with some big power shots as Perry tries to charge forward and apply his aggression. Pick: Jake Paul via TKO6\n\nWho wins Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry, and which prop is a must-back? {"uri": "8232202058", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "17:24:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T17:24:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T17:22:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/sports/jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-would-loss-paul-put-mike-tyson-fight-jeopardy-1927167", "title": "Jake Paul vs Mike Perry: Would a Loss by Paul Put Tyson Fight in Jeopardy?", "body": "Jake Paul continues to change the landscape of the boxing game by welcoming bigger and bigger challenges. The \"Problem Child\" booked his biggest fight to date, when it was announced he would face off against legendary former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson on July 20 in Arlington, Texas.\n\nMore news: Jake Paul Reportedly Targeting MMA Debut in 2025\n\nThe issue is Tyson is 58 years old, and worries about his age and health came into question immediately after the fight was announced. To make matters worse, Tyson suffered a \"medical scare\" during a flight from Miami to Los Angeles in May.\n\nTyson apparently suffered an ulcer flare-up and had to be attended to by medical professionals when the flight landed. The result of the flare-up was that doctors told Tyson he could not train fully.\n\nThe scheduled bout between Tyson and Paul was then postponed from July 20 to Nov. 15. Instead of training harder, Paul found a new opponent for July 20.\n\nIt was announced that Paul would face off against former UFC and current undefeated BKFC (Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship) fighter Mike Perry. Perry is a dangerous striker and could be the biggest challenge to date for Paul.\n\nAs stated, Perry is undefeated in the BKFC. He has defeated former and current UFC fighters like Michael Page, Luke Rockhold, Eddie Alvarez, and Thiago Alves. Perry also holds a 14-8 MMA record, with notable wins over Mickey Gall, Alex Oliveira, and Paul Felder.\n\nPerry is known for his powerful striking. Though he has not yet tried his hand at professional boxing, his experience in the octagon and BKFC could spell trouble for Paul.\n\nPaul joined DAZN Boxing to talk about his fighting journey, and what kind of a threat Perry poses to him.\n\nAccording to Paul, \"A lot of people think I'm crazy for pivoting to this; why Mike Perry, why now, why take the risk, you could lose the biggest payday of your life against Mike Tyson if you lose to Mike Perry who is a violent killer, a bare-knuckle, undefeated legend over there. He takes punches like they're nothing, he's fast, athletic, he hits hard, he's a brawler, and I can't take that lightly. This whole thing is a risk, I'm focused on July 20, I'm focused on Mike Perry, and being in that mindset will lead me to victory.\"\n\nPaul is very self-aware of the fact that Perry is not a pushover in the sport of fighting. He is a renowned striker and a person that could easily knock Paul out.\n\nThe other important aspect of Paul's comments is he is risking a huge payday if he were to have to drop out of his fight with Tyson. No one has yet to fully damage or knock out Paul, but both of those could happen in his bout with Perry.\n\nThe boxing commission could step in and prevent Paul from fighting Tyson depending on the damage that he has sustained in his fight with Perry. This could be especially true if he were to get knocked out.\n\nMost fighters don't typically take fights within six months of being knocked out, for fear they could face another knockout. There is also the danger of being cut open and needing stitches to worry about.\n\nAgain, Perry is a violent striker and too much damage to Paul's face could also lead to the commission stepping in and preventing his fight with Tyson in November.\n\nPaul has only lost once in his professional boxing career, which was to Tommy Fury in Feb. 2023. The fight went in favor of Tommy by a split decision. Even then Paul was not damaged that much, so it stands to reason he should be able to hold his own against Perry.\n\nTime will tell if Perry gets the victory over Paul on July 20. Paul vs. Perry headlines a card featuring multiple boxing champions at the Amalie Arena in Tampa, Florida on Saturday.\n\nPaul (9-1) looks to add another former UFC fighter to his resume after beating Nate Diaz, Anderson Silva, Tyron Woodley (twice) and Ben Askren. Mike Perry (0-1) is a heavy-handed mixed martial artist who revitalized his career with a 5-0 run in bare-knuckle boxing. Perry gives up size and boxing experience to Paul but he's among the most competent UFC alum available to challenge Paul in the squared circle. Paul is taking a substantial risk by fighting Perry four months before a major box office fight with Tyson.\n\n\"The skills is what pay the bills. And he has no footwork, no head movement, no defense,\" Paul said at the final press conference. \"He's a great offensive fighter and bare knuckle, but in terms of boxing, he's going to get picked apart very quickly, and it's going to be a short night. It's going to happen, put money on it.\"\n\nThe undercard is fairly typical for a crossover boxing event with some former and current champions along with another former UFC fighter looking to make the jump. Undisputed women's featherweight champion Amanda Serrano is in action when she takes on Stevie Morgan in the featured bout. Serrano was also expected to compete on the Tyson card in a rematch with undisputed two-division queen Katie Taylor. But with the postponement, Serrano wanted to stay active with a bout before November, especially after having her fight in March fall through on the day of the fight.\n\n\"Listen, I don't pay attention to that. That doesn't win fights, that doesn't pay my bills. Eddie Hearn doubts Perry's chances against Paul due to his weight disadvantage and boxing experience, predicting a win for Paul. Despite Paul's victorious record against UFC fighters, Perry's focus on boxing and size advantage make him a formidable opponent.\n\nJake Paul returns to the boxing ring on Saturday, July 20, at the Amalie Arena, where he will face former UFC fighter and BKFC star Platinum Mike Perry.\n\nPerry stepped in to replace Mike Tyson, who was initially scheduled to fight Paul at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, TX, for Netflix's first-ever live sports event.\n\nTyson's illness led to the postponement of his match with Paul until November, prompting Perry's inclusion to keep the original date.\n\nRelated\n\nMike Perry Vows to 'Get Dirty' Against Jake Paul in Upcoming Fight\n\nMike Perry shares 'dirty' sparring footage, promises to use the same tactics in his Jake Paul fight.\n\nEddie Hearn Explains Why Mike Perry Will Lose To Jake Paul\n\nThe Matchroom Boss Puts It's Down To Size\n\nClose\n\nIn a recent interview with DAZN, Eddie Hearn expressed strong doubts about Perry's chances against Paul. \"Mike Perry is a welterweight who fought at middleweight in the UFC, and this fight is at 200 pounds. He has absolutely no chance,\" Hearn stated. He acknowledged Perry's toughness, especially at lower weights, but emphasized the significant weight disadvantage. Hearn added, \"Jake's not great, but he's big, strong, and can punch a little bit. I think he'll stop Mike Perry.\"\n\nHearn also commented on Paul's career trajectory, suggesting that the \"Jake Paul machine works when he's in a big fight.\" He noted that while there's some interest in Perry as an opponent, a fight with Mike Tyson if it happens, would draw much more attention. Hearn highlighted Paul's dilemma between seeking credibility as a boxer and participating in influencer fights for greater financial gain. \"He wants to establish himself as a credible boxer but can't fight anyone too good because he'll get beat,\" Hearn concluded.\n\nMike Perry Poses Serious Threat To Jake Paul\n\nJake Paul (9-1) seeks to add another former UFC fighter to his list of conquests, following victories over Nate Diaz, Anderson Silva, Tyron Woodley (twice), and Ben Askren. His opponent, Mike Perry (0-1), is a heavy-handed mixed martial artist who has revitalized his career with a 5-0 run in bare-knuckle boxing.\n\nDespite giving up size and boxing experience to Paul, Perry is considered one of the most competent UFC alumni available to challenge him in the ring. This bout presents a significant risk for Paul, especially with a major box office fight against Mike Tyson looming four months later.\n\nIn BKFC, Perry has defeated much larger opponents such as former UFC middleweight champion Luke Rockhold. {"uri": "2024-07-427707927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "02:34:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T02:34:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T02:34:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/jake-paul-shoves-mike-perry-and-sparks-on-stage-brawl-as-weigh-in-ahead-of-boxing-showdown-descends-into-chaos/", "title": "Jake Paul SHOVES Mike Perry and sparks on-stage brawl as weigh-in ahead of boxing showdown descends into chaos", "body": "Jake Paul may no longer be fighting Mike Tyson on Saturday in a main-event boxing match, but that does not mean there will not be any fireworks with his new opponent, Mike Perry.\n\nDuring Friday's pre-fight faceoff, Paul and Perry had the traditional stare down with plenty of trash talk between the two. Talk nearly turned into fists flying.\n\nPerry put his hands on Paul first, with Paul getting a much stronger shove off to Perry, sending him back.\n\nSecurity for the fighters were surrounding both men, quickly putting themselves in between the combatants before the physicality ramped up.\n\nIt took several members of security to hold Perry back from getting a chance to swing on Paul before the fight officially began.\n\nJake Paul and Mike Perry nearly came to blows during their pre-fight stare down\n\nPaul pumped up the crowd after shoving Mike Perry, forcing security to intervene\n\nWhile security held back Perry, Paul pumped up the crowd and looked happy with himself.\n\n'He light. He flew like six feet,' Paul said after the confrontation.\n\nPaul also claimed UFC President Dana White would give Perry a contract if he knocks him out in the fight.\n\n'You can rip up the f****n contract because I'm going to f*** up Mike Perry,' Paul said. 'Anyone you send at me, anyone of your MMA fighters is getting f****d up. They been trying to assassinate me.'\n\n'They don't want me in this sport,' Paul continued. 'They hate that I run this sport. But when you try to assassinate a guy like me, it only makes me bigger. I'm on a mission from God.'\n\nPerry is also using the publicity of being Mike Tyson's replacement to promote himself and his new promotion, Dirty Boxing Championship, which will be a combination of Muay Thai, boxing, and MMA.\n\nPaul has fought Ben Askren, Tyron Woodley, Nate Diaz, and Anderson Silva, all of whom have UFC backgrounds and holds a 9-1 professional record.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8233557097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "13:07:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T13:07:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:06:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.mmafighting.com/2024/7/19/24199166/paul-vs-perry-roundtable-is-mike-perry-primed-to-spoil-the-jake-paul-party", "title": "Paul vs. Perry roundtable: Is Mike Perry primed to spoil the Jake Paul party?", "body": "It's time for another bizarro crossover boxing match!\n\nYes, we were just here two weeks ago, when MMA stars Nate Diaz and Jorge Masvidal threw down in a shockingly entertaining contest. Now, it's the king of influencer boxers Paul taking on BKFC's king of violence Perry. Paul's controversial matchup with Mike Tyson was rescheduled for Nov. 15, but will he even make it to that date once Perry is through with him? MMA Fighting's Shaun Al-Shatti, Alexander K. Lee, and Damon Martin take an all-angles look at Saturday's event, a matchup that could have far-reaching implications for both men.\n\nAl-Shatti: I suppose that depends on what we mean by dangerous.\n\nIf dangerous means \"the man most capable of sending Paul's head into orbit,\" there's a good argument to be made that both Tyron Woodley and Anderson Silva were far more accomplished knockout artists than Perry. If dangerous means \"the man most capable of beating Paul in a professional boxing match,\" Tommy Fury clearly takes that mantle considering, one, he's an actual professional boxer, and two, he actually defeated Paul in the squared circle. So in that regard, no, Perry doesn't stack up to some of the names already on Paul's r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\n\nBut if we're talking about dangerous in a more abstract sense -- i.e. \"the total wildcard most capable of just doing really wild shit in there, and potentially teaching Paul a lesson about himself that he'd really rather not learn\" -- then good lord, absolutely, 100 percent, BKFC's King of Violence is the most dangerous man Paul has ever come across. Perry has already broken far tougher and more decorated men than Paul, he brings an inherent ferocity to any arena that few people on Earth can match -- and low-key, he has a knack for playing spoiler in situations where his skill set alone should realistically fall short. Just ask Michael Seals. As the great Charlie Kelly once showed, no one can ruin plans quicker than the wildcard.\n\nLee: Jake Paul has been in there with some kooky characters, but he's really rolling the dice getting in there with Mike Perry.\n\nOver the past couple of years, Perry has done a lot to change his image from a middling MMA welterweight with serious outside-of-the-cage issues (including domestic violence allegations raised by his ex-wife and his mother) to legitimate bare-knuckle boxing star. Whether you buy this rehabilitation is up to you, but there's no question that he's become a fan favorite and a big-enough name to be booked for this high-profile opportunity.\n\nPerry has retained the most important part of his act: When the bell rings, you're in for a hell of a show, and when it comes to his BKFC career, it's typically been at the expense of his opponents. Luke Rockhold. Eddie Alvarez. Thiago Alves. All of these former UFC standouts left the BKFC ring with a slightly different face shape than they had before they traded punches with Perry. I hope Paul subscribes to the \"chicks dig scars\" theory because he's likely to have a couple of new ones after this weekend, even with the big gloves in play.\n\nWin or lose, Perry goes in there to hurt, and he has more knockout power than anyone Paul has fought before. Sorry, Jake, this isn't going to be Tommy Fury pitter-pattering you to snooze-worthy decision loss. If you lose on Saturday, it will be because Perry checked that chin. Should that happen, there's no telling how much psychological damage that could do to Paul on top of the physical.\n\nMartin: Based on what we actually know about Jake Paul and the opponents he's faced, Mike Perry is by far the most dangerous for a few different reasons.\n\nWhen Paul first started touting himself as a future boxing champion, no one really knew what to expect. Beating up influencers on the undercard of your brother's events doesn't exactly tell us much. Flat-lining an NBA player like Nate Robinson shows you have knockout power, but that still doesn't mean you can box.\n\nPaul did pick up a number of wins over legitimately talented MMA fighters, but even those victories can be picked apart. Tyron Woodley is one the best welterweights of all-time, but he's a wrestler with knockout power. That certainly doesn't mean he's a boxer. Ben Askren is a wrestler with no hands. Anderson Silva was pushing 50 years old. Nate Diaz is a lightweight. You get the point.\n\nBut Mike Perry is actually in the prime of his fighting career at 32 years old and he's spent the past few years doing nothing but striking as a bare-knuckle boxing superstar at BKFC. Perry arguably has a better win on his record than Paul does -- as far as boxing is concerned -- when he beat Michael Seals in a special rule set match back in 2021.\n\nPerry is ferocious, powerful, and relentless in the ring, and he has the kind of \"I don't give a f*ck\" attitude that allows him the freedom to go head-hunting on Paul from the first second until the last. Could that potentially cost him? Of course. Perry often eats as many punches as he throws, but playing that game with him can (and usually does) end in disaster.\n\nIf Paul has dollar signs in his eyes waiting to beat up 58-year-old Mike Tyson in November, he might just get cashed out by a savage Perry come Saturday night.\n\nAl-Shatti: Not a chance.\n\nMuch like other \"Ultra Famous Dudes Who Also Fight\" -- i.e. the Conor McGregor category -- Paul's allure to the general audience isn't built on preserving the sanctity of some unblemished record. If it was, this whole saga would've ended 17 months ago once he lost to Tommy Fury. Jake Paul vs. Mike Tyson is the type of fight Netflix wants because it's the type of fight that gets audiences young and old alike morbidly interested to watch the car crash. I guarantee you the grandfather shopping in the dairy aisle of the grocery store doesn't care if Mike Perry sends Paul to the land of wind and ghosts on Saturday, just as the 12-year-old who grew up indoctrinated in Paulmania doesn't care if Perry goes out there and Rockholds the YouTuber. The former likely won't even find out and the latter is going to continue riding-or-dying for their childhood hero regardless of what happens in Tampa.\n\nHell, if Paul actually does lose this weekend, it may actually boost interest from the endlessly vocal \"Tyson Has No Chance Because He's So Damn Old\" crowd.\n\nEither way, Paul's rabid fan base isn't going away and the spectacle of watching a near-mythical beast like Tyson do his thing while he's still around will remain as strong as ever.\n\nLee: It really could!\n\nLook, I get that there's been so much money and marketing muscle put into Paul vs. Tyson that it seems like the matchup will happen come hell or high water, even though it's unclear who is actually looking forward this accursed event at this point. But if there was ever an excuse for Paul to ask for a postponement, wouldn't a few brutal rounds with Perry be it?\n\nAdmittedly, there's probably not a lot of crossover between the people tuning in this Saturday and the people tuning in Nov. 15, but should Paul have a poor showing against Perry, word will get out. Not to mention the possibility of an unfortunate moment for Paul going viral. Imagine if Perry manages to land a shot that has Paul touching canvas. That will be replied a million times over the next four months and suddenly there's a whole new narrative heading into the Tyson fight.\n\nI'll go as far as to argue that Paul needs to not only beat Perry, he has to look good doing it. Your average, normal, non-combat sports obsessed human being has no clue who Perry is. If he ends up humbling Paul, it will be a massive blow to the 27-year-old's brand. Tyson vs. Paul will still draw massive interest, but it definitely loses some shine if Paul is coming off of a loss to a far less famous bare-knuckle boxer.\n\nMartin: It's tough to say, but really that decision ultimately lies with Netflix.\n\nThe streaming service is footing the bill to promote this bizarre boxing match between a social influencer and an aging legend who is much closer to being an octogenarian than he is a teenager. Weirdly, a compelling loss where Paul gets into a grueling war with a savage like Perry might actually convince a few more people that Tyson has a chance to beat him.\n\nThen again, Paul getting absolutely demolished and then turning around to fight again in November might be a tough stretch, so that's where the questions come in. So technically the answer is yes, it's possible that Perry costs Paul the fight with Tyson, but it seems unlikely.\n\nThrough 10 fights in his career, Paul's brand has been built around spectacle more than wins or losses. While he still references his split decision loss to Tommy Fury from time to time, that barely registers as a blip on Paul's radar these days.\n\nFor a guy who keeps touting his plan to win championships and beat up guys like Canelo Alvarez, Paul's real agenda involves taking on big names and cashing even bigger checks. The Tyson fight might lose some luster if Paul gets face-planted by Perry, but otherwise this matchup is more than likely moving ahead as scheduled.\n\nAl-Shatti: Mike Perry's bank account.\n\nFor real, not since Jorge Masvidal exploded into a superstar overnight in 2019 have we seen a financial transformation that compares to what Perry has undergone since leaving the UFC. This is a man who lost seven of his last 10 octagon bouts -- and suddenly, three years later, is a multi-millionaire with promotional juice for days and no end to this gold rush in sight. Let that be a lesson to us all. Sometimes the key to life really is just finding where you fit in the world rather than stubbornly trying to force a square peg to fit into a round hole.\n\nBut to answer the actual question, Paul wins a fight that's grimier than his usual but clearly shows the difference between the brutecraft of bare-knuckle boxing and the oh-so-sweet science of the big-gloved arts. Perry is going to bring the fight and test Paul's mettle in a way it's never been tested before, but ultimately the YouTuber will be too large and too long for the BKFC star. Expect Paul to get on his bike and jab his way to victory as the rounds wear on and those 10-ounce gloves protect him from the kind of facial reconstruction Perry's last few opponents have come to enjoy. Jake Paul via unanimous decision.\n\nLee: Paul.\n\nFor all the doomsaying I've written above, this should be a pit-stop on the way to Paul's more prestigious punch-up with Tyson in November. Perry has been saying a lot about how Paul has no concept of how different bare-knuckle boxing is, but I think Perry should consider that he's never been in a traditional boxing match with this kind of circus around it. Like it or not, he's in Paul's world now.\n\nJake Paul is, at best, an above average boxer relative to his level of experience, and that should still be enough to handle Perry. The size and athleticism of Paul have carried him through some tough spots and I don't expect that to change when he crosses swords with \"Platinum.\" Perry is wild, dangerous, and unpredictable, but does he have more surprises up his sleeve than a Nate Diaz or an Anderson Silva? Doubtful.\n\nIt's more likely that the always well-prepared Paul feasts on Perry's aggression, while wisely avoiding the taunts to \"bring it on\" that are sure to be peppered throughout the contest. Perry will do his best to make it nasty, but Paul won't bite.\n\nEventually, the larger Paul will lock in on Perry, pick up on a fatal tell, and take out the face of BKFC in the sixth round.\n\nMartin: On paper, Paul should win based on his overall experience in boxing and the ability to do just enough to cruise to victory as he did in past fights against guys like Silva and Diaz. Paul didn't take too many unnecessary risks against either of them but he did manage a brief knockdown in both to help him get the nod on the scorecards.\n\nJust for a moment, however, let's think about how Perry can pull off the upset.\n\nHe's a hard-charging bull with devastating knockout power in both hands and the grit and moxie to make this a slugfest. If Perry can lure his foe into the kind of fight where Paul can't dictate the pace and actually has to just stand and trade punches round after round, this becomes a much closer contest.\n\nPerry's aggressive style could easily cost him, especially with Paul carrying around a nuclear bomb in his right hand, but he presents problems the 27-year-old fighter from Cleveland just hasn't faced before. In his lone loss, Paul only had to deal with Tommy Fury dancing on the outside and sticking a jab in his face for eight rounds and not much else happened.\n\nThat's not going to happen with Perry. He's going to be in Paul's face from the first second until the last, and he'll be throwing heavy leather behind every punch. To add to that, Perry has always shown effective conditioning, even though he's constantly throwing heat-seeking missiles, but cardio has been a problem for Paul in the past.\n\nThat's why my pick is this being the night that Paul goes night-night, perhaps late in the seventh or eighth round just as Perry predicted.", "source": {"uri": "mmafighting.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MMA Fighting"}, "authors": [{"uri": "alexander_k_lee@mmafighting.com", "name": "Alexander K. Perry appears to be lost in the chaos as the big-bodied security guards attempt to calm things down.\n\nPaul was initially supposed to fight Mike Tyson on July 20, but a \"medical scare\" on a recent flight led to Tyson having to take some time off from training. Paul vs. Tyson was then postponed to Nov. 15.\n\nPaul could have easily taken some extra time to train, but the boxer instead decided to book a last-minute opponent in Perry. Highlights from Jake Paul vs Mike Perry press conference ahead of boxing showdown in Florida", "body": "Highlights and best moments from the explosive press conference between Jake Paul and Mike Perry ahead of their boxing showdown this weekend.\n\nAfter a bitter war of words, both on social media and at the recent press conference, the stage is finally set for Jake 'The Problem Child' Paul and 'Platinum' Mike Perry to finally lock horns in the boxing ring.\n\nThe press conference started with Jake Paul actually thanking Mike Perry for 'beating up' his mascot at the open weigh-ins, claiming that the PR stunt only serves to market his new company, 'W'.\n\nIn turn, Perry exclaimed that he's going to finish Jake Paul for the various communities he represents in the world of combat sports; from Mixed Martial Arts all the way to Bare-Knuckle.\n\n\"I'm doing this for everybody, for me, for the fans, for BKFC, for MMA, just mainly for me because I believe in myself and my boxing ability - I'm a brawling, boxing mug so I'm ready to get in the ring with Jake and have some fun.\"\n\nYet the conversation quickly shifted to the comments made by one Conor McGregor, who certainly had some choice words for Paul as he held a BKFC press conference in Marbella only a few hours earlier.\n\n\"First of all, he's bigging up BKFC but you're going to see what I'm going to do to their best fighter on Saturday night, I'm going to embarrass the whole entire league. This guy has no skill, those are just brawler-idiot-street fighter dudes who have no idea what the sweet science is.\n\n\"Conor McGregor can say what he wants but he won't fight me either so once I knock out Mike Perry, Conor McGregor- let's run it, but you won't... Layoff the c******, get in the gym, start winning fights and then maybe we can start having a conversation.\"\n\nThat comment on BKFC immediately got the attention of Perry, who lambasted the crowd for clapping and cheering Jake's jibe: \"He's a disrespectful punk, those men and women fight for their families over there, they get in that ring, and they put on a show for the fans!\"\n\nContrary to popular belief, Perry isn't making his boxing debut on Saturday, having lost his only previous fight back in 2015; with Jake Paul stating that he's studied footage from that bout extremely closely:\n\n\"He had a boxing match in a triangle that I gained a lot of knowledge from, [he leaves] a lot of openings and it's going to be a short night. He's open for anything that I want to throw at him.\"\n\n\"But I've been winning since then,\" countered Perry, \"That's all I know, I've been victorious consistently and I've been getting better every single day to put this little twerp in his place - welcome, welcome, you just got here.\"\n\nThe pair then started the first of many arguments shouting over the top of each other; with Paul arguing that Perry should be considered the newcomer as he's 0-1 in boxing, whilst 'Platinum' pointed out that he's had over 30 professional fights.\n\n\"That's cool and I'm [still] going to beat you - isn't that crazy? I'm 0-1 but how many pro boxers have you fought? Two guys and the last one - ey, I'm glad you got your shirt open so everyone can see your fat a** belly - you're as fat as the last guy you knocked out and you barely knocked him out!\n\n\"Don't worry, you're going to get what you've been asking for - for the fight to go longer than one round; I'm going to give you hell in the first, second, just wait and watch... Then you're going to get tired and be grasping for air - I just made up a new word, grasping. You're going to be grasping for air.\"\n\nIrritated by Perry questioning his physique, Paul noted that he expects to weigh around 215lbs after rehydrating on Saturday evening, Perry in turn said he'll probably weigh in around 194-196lbs.\n\n\"That doesn't matter, none of that matters - skills are what pay the bills,\" noted Paul, adding that whilst Perry is a fantastic fighter when he's on the front foot in Bare-Knuckle, he lacks the necessary head movement and defense to survive 'The Problem Child'.\n\n\"He's going to get picked apart very quickly and it's going to be a short night. My predictions are never wrong, so I stand on business every time... I will knock out Mike Perry in less than two rounds, put some money on it.\"\n\n\"You got beat by Love Island boy,\" Perry interjected, referencing Paul's loss to Tommy Fury in 2023- \"Love Island boy beat you up and he ain't no killer and he [still] beat you up,\"\n\nIt was at this point when Paul brought out a 'gift' for his opponent, a graduation cap with 'Private School Perry' written on its top- Perry tossed it into the air and claimed victory, \"I never got to do this - I'm graduating before I beat your a** on Saturday!\"\n\nThe questions would then be opened up to the audience and let's just say that there were some interesting statements being floated around the Amalie Arena stage.\n\nThe pair then finally squared off in an intense moment in front of a rather subdued crowd.\n\nDespite having a rematch with Katie Taylor already booked for November 15, Amanda Serrano, one of the greatest female boxers of all time, returns to action to face 8-1 American Stevie Morgan.\n\nWhilst not many questions were directed their way, there was certainly some tension on stage between the two following comments that Morgan made about Serrano being one of the weaker fighters on the women's pound-for-pound rankings.\n\nAmanda Serrano: \"Listen, I don't pay attention to that, that doesn't win fights and that doesn't pay my bills, I go out, I train hard, I fight hard, and you'll see Saturday night.\"\n\nStevie Morgan: \"I'm not being disrespectful at all; I'm just stating facts. If I had to pick any of the fighters at the top, Amanda Serrano would be the one I would choose mainly because she's going to make me look good.\"\n\nThe full card for 'Fear No Man', the title of the Perry was the first to put his hands on Paul but the internet sensation responded by shoving the bare knuckle bruiser so hard he disappeared off-camera. Despite Perry's fighting history in BKFC, Paul may hold the upper hand in strength and experience in boxing-rules contests.\n\nJake Paul and Mike Perry got into a shoving match on stage during a weigh-in just one day before their crossover, boxing-rules fight in Tampa, Florida, which airs on PPV.com.\n\nThough those in MMA circles are tipping Perry to provide Paul with a stern test, it will likely be business as usual for the internet sensation who took the boxing world by storm after feasting on pro athletes, former MMA champions, and a few journeyman boxers. The gulf in boxing-rules experience therefore favors Paul, despite the wild and fan-friendly fighting nature Perry has shown in his foray into the sport of bare knuckle, after a run in UFC.\n\nPaul may have an additional advantage heading into the fight, if pre-fight body language and weigh-in theatrics can be used to determine the probable outcome. This is because Paul showed he could be the naturally-stronger athlete heading into Saturday's showdown.\n\nRelated What Mike Perry is Wearing Around his Neck Ahead of Jake Paul Fight\n\nThis is what Mike Perry is wearing around his neck ahead of the Jake Paul fight in boxing.\n\nPaul Shoved Perry so Hard he Disappeared Off-Camera Perry laid his hands on Paul first, but came out second best\n\nWeigh-ins can often pass fight fans and media members by with little to no newsworthy events but every now and then they provide a promise of fireworks to come if there is any controversial trash-talk, or incidents in which one, or both, fighters lay their hands on one another.\n\nPerry was first to put his hands on Paul as he gave his opponent a slight push on the chest, to which Paul rapidly responded with a full on shove which pushed Perry so hard he disappeared off-camera. It was a wild indication that the 6-foot-1 Paul, who is three inches taller and, likely, at least 15 pounds heavier, may well be the naturally stronger athlete.\n\nWatch the pushing and shoving match right here:\n\nJake Paul Will Hope to Emerge Unscathed 'The Problem Child' has a big event to look forward to later this year\n\nPaul will hope to emerge unscathed against Perry, in a victory that would advance his pro boxing record to 10 wins (with 7 KOs should he secure the finish this weekend).\n\nThe more thrilling the win, the likelier it is that Paul will recapture some momentum he's lost as recent fights -- like the ones against Andre August and Ryan Bourland went under the radar.\n\nOn November 15 Paul is scheduled to fight Mike Tyson at the AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas. {"uri": "8234883004", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "11:14:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T11:14:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T11:14:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/boxing/article-13644691/Jake-Paul-Mike-Perry-Tyson-fight.html", "title": "Watch out, Jake Paul - Mike Perry has dangerous bareknuckle reputation", "body": "Once among the most anticipated fights of 2024, Jake Paul's return to the boxing ring on Saturday night in Tampa has lost some luster since 58-year-old opponent Mike Tyson suffered a medical emergency on a May flight from Miami to Los Angeles.\n\nCiting an ulcer flareup, Tyson has since agreed to postpone his bout with the 27-year-old Paul until November 15, thereby allowing bareknuckle fighter and ex-UFC star 'Platinum' Mike Perry to step in on Saturday in his place.\n\nIt's obviously an unusual situation: Perry, at 32, is becoming a headliner in just his second career boxing match because a former heavyweight champion 26 years his senior has a festering sore in his stomach lining.\n\nBut to anyone who witnessed Thursday's profane press conference, where the trash-talking Perry (0-1) matched Paul (9-1) insult for insult, the converted boxer appeared right at home as a headliner. The two came to blows on Friday night, as well, as the weigh-in nearly turned into a brawl before Saturday's showdown.\n\nAnd while Paul has dismissed Saturday's bout as a 'Mike appetizer' and 'Mike warmup,' press conference moderator and MMA aficionado Ariel Helwani reliably called Perry 'one of the toughest SOBs on the planet.' Now Perry has a chance to make a name for himself, not only by beating a wildly famous former YouTube star, but by putting that November 15 Paul-Tyson fight in jeopardy with a stunning upset: 'I'm a crazy [expletive] and I'm here to fight.'\n\nAn exasperated Jake Paul shuts his eyes as Mike Perry talks trash to the crowd in Tampa\n\nAfter serving as a backup fighter for two Paul bouts, Perry (right) gets his chance Saturday\n\nRead More Jake Paul SHOVES Mike Perry and sparks on-stage brawl as weigh-in descends into chaos\n\nA combat sports enthusiast and professional for the better part of the last decade, Perry's route to the top of this fight card isn't any more bizarre than Paul's.\n\nThat former Disney Channel star and YouTuber has made millions as an 'influencer' boxer and promoter, all without ever beating a recognizable pugilist - something his bout with Tyson was intended to remedy.\n\nPerry obviously doesn't have Tyson's boxing resume, but he does have other advantages over the Hall of Famer.\n\nSpecifically, Perry was born after the Lyndon Johnson administration, he hasn't qualified for AARP membership, and while he has only one other boxing match on his record - a knockout loss in 2015 - he does have a dangerous reputation on the bareknuckle circuit, where he's 5-0.\n\nThe question is, can Perry make make fans forget about Tyson's absence?\n\nPerry's 0-1 boxing record aside, Paul's challenger began training in the sport as an 11-year-old. In fact, he was actually from one of the sport's hotbeds, Flint, Michigan, where two-time gold medalist Claressa Shields and former super middleweight titlist Anthony Dirrell were both born.\n\nGrowing up in Michigan and Florida, Perry struggled with bullying and as a result, began getting into fights at school.\n\n'[In Michigan] I was one of maybe 10 white kids in the whole school, so I was bullied a lot,' he told MMA Junkie in 2015. 'It was the same thing at other schools. I wouldn't back down, so I would get into fights.'\n\nFighting didn't help Perry make honor roll, but it did provide him with a career path.\n\nStanding 5-foot-10, Perry began pursuing a career in mixed-martial arts and quickly established himself as a talented striker with nine knockouts to start his career.\n\nMike Perry points to a miniaturized Jake Paul head that he has attached to a chain on his neck\n\nPlatinum Mike Perry Shows off his skills during a recent open workout in Tampa\n\nMike Perry bleeds profusely during UFC Fight Night at the Amway Center in Orlando in 2018\n\nThe problem was, Perry wasn't entirely done with being a troublemaker.\n\n'I played Grand Theft Auto, and I wanted to be like that, I wanted it to be easy like that,' he told MMA Junkie in 2015. 'I smoked drugs, I carried guns, and I thought I was a gangster.'\n\nThere was an arrest for burglary, a two-year community control sentence, which is similar to house arrest, and a failed drug test resulting in a few months in jail for the aspiring MMA fighter.\n\nIn the end, it was the stint behind bars that Perry claimed set him straight.\n\n'The day I got out of jail, I showed up at the UFC gym in Winter Springs [Florida],' he told MMA Junkie, 'and it's been good ever since then.'\n\nHe'd go on to make his debut in the octagon at UFC 202 in 2016 filling in for another fighter, Sultan Aliev, who was forced to withdraw due to injury.\n\nFacing veteran South Korean welterweight Lim Hyun-Gyu, Perry earned a stunning first-round knockout victory, albeit one that was tarnished by allegations of racism against Perry's cornerman, Alex Nicholson.\n\n'He can't even open his mother***ing eyes,' Nicholson was heard saying during pre-fight introductions.\n\nMike Perry reacts after the conclusion of his welterweight fight against Vicente Luque in 2019\n\nJake Paul has dismissed Mike Perry as a mere 'appetizer' before his postponed Mike Tyson bout\n\nNicholson later apologized on Twitter, but Perry leaned into the comment days after his debut victory.\n\n'I don't think any of my competition can see me, and when I hit him, I opened a lot of people's eyes,' Perry told the MMA Hour's Ariel Helwani.\n\nPerry's victory over Hyun-Gyu and another knockout win over Danny Roberts helped to raise his profile, and he was soon facing tougher competition. He'd go on to earn consecutive 'Performance of the Night' honors in 2017 with knockout wins over Jake Ellenberger and Alex Reyes.\n\nBut as his competition improved, his record quickly fell from 11-1 in 2017 to just 14-8 by April of 2021.\n\nSo Perry left the Octagon and entered the fledgling Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship, where his striking power made him an immediate success.\n\n'He does have one-punch knockout power that I do have to respect,' Paul told reporters Thursday. 'But other than that, it's going to be easy.'\n\nPerry and Tyson have more than Jake Paul in common.\n\nLike Tyson, who has been convicted for everything rape to drugs, Perry has found himself on the wrong side of the law on several occasions.\n\nThere was an alleged 2016 incident in which Perry was accused of knocking a man unconscious after he approached the fighter's then-girlfriend.\n\nA similar situation unfolded in 2020, when Perry was accused of knocking out an elderly man. Perry was ultimately charged with a misdemeanor after telling police that he did not initiate any physical contact.\n\nBut Perry may have been at rock bottom in 2020, when his ex-wife and former tennis pro Danielle Nickerson told MMA Junkie that he had been violent with her.\n\nHe has denied the allegations and no charges were ever filed, although Perry did tell MMA Junkie that he has received help for both alcohol abuse and anger management issues.\n\n'I did not put hands on my ex at any point in our short term [sic] marriage,' Perry said.\n\n'I have realized that I have said some things in the past that do not put me and what I stand for in the best of light and for that I apologize,' he continued. I am now in a loving relationship where I am looking forward and excited to welcoming [sic] my first born. I'm hopeful my ex can move on and find peace as I have.'\n\nEven this week, Perry ignited some concerns by attacking a mascot at Wednesday's workout and ultimately needed to be restrained.\n\nMike Perry took on a mascot during his open workout on Wednesday in Tampa\n\nUltimately Perry needed to be pulled off the defeated mascot at Wednesday's workout\n\nBut if Perry has found peace outside the ring, he's also enjoying some newfound success between the ropes.\n\nIn April, he scored a first-round knockout over light heavyweight Thago Alves at BKFC Knucklemania IV to improve his bareknuckle record to 5-0.\n\nAnd this is where Perry finds himself now: An undefeated bareknuckle fighter trying to make an impact on the world of boxing.\n\nWith a win over Paul, Tyson's November 15 bout with the 'Problem Child' and its million-dollar purses would all be at risk. And while he claims he's unconcerned, Paul revealed he did get a phone call from Tyson to make sure he has Saturday's bout under control.\n\n'Tyson was concerned about me taking this fight,' Paul told reporters at Wednesday's workouts, as quoted by MMA Mania. 'He's like, ''What is Jake thinking? This guy Mike Perry is a killer.'' So he had some concerns. But Tyson, my message to you is don't worry. I'm going to put this guy to sleep. This is a Mike appetizer and you're next.'\n\nPerry, for his part, envisions things going in a much different - and far gorier - direction.\n\n'Your little baby green punches can't even reach my brain stem, bro,' Perry told Paul during a recent faceoff on DAZN. 'I'm going to dig through your eyeball and find your memories.'", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8233799103", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "15:53:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T15:53:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:52:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://deadspin.com/jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-preview-rules-predictions/", "title": "Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry Preview, Rules, Predictions | Deadspin.com", "body": "Jake Paul (9-1, 6 KOs) returns to the ring Saturday night for the second time in 2024.\n\nBut instead of the summer blockbuster with Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion and arguably one of the greatest boxers of all time, it's BKFC standout Mike Perry in the ring for his second career boxing match (0-1).\n\nPaul has quickly established himself as a boxer to watch. Some pundits and experts still doubt his boxing ability given that his lone fight against a trained boxer with previous in-ring experience was a losing effort in February 2023 against Tommy Fury.\n\nPerry spent five years in the UFC. He had a record of 7-8 before departing the promotion in 2021. Despite his below-.500 mark in the Octagon, he did earn notable wins against long-time veterans Paul Felder and Jake Ellenberger.\n\nPerry has found success in BKFC and currently maintains a five-fight winning streak against a mix of former UFC champions and ex-contenders, including Eddie Alvarez, former UFC middleweight champion Luke Rockhold, and current welterweight contender Michael Page.\n\nPerry's last bare-knuckle win came in April, knocking out ex-UFC welterweight title challenger Thiago Alves and needing less than a round to get the victory.\n\nAlthough Paul and Perry showed a level of respect for one another at Thursday's pre-fight press conference in Tampa, Fla., it remains all business come fight night.\n\n\"The skills is what pay the bills,\" Paul said. \"And he has no footwork, no head movement, no defense. He's a great offensive fighter and bare-knuckle, but in terms of boxing, he's going to get picked apart very quickly, and it's going to be a short night. Like I said, my predictions are never wrong, so I stand on business every single time I manifested into reality. I, Jake Joseph Paul, will knock out Mike Perry in less than two rounds. It's going to happen; put money on it.\"\n\nPerry has competed in combat sports for over a decade. He said Paul was mistaken for discrediting his boxing ability.\n\n\"Don't worry, you're going to get what you've been asking for -- the fight to go longer than one round,\" Perry said. \"[I'm going to] give you hell in the first round, and you'll get tired. You're going to be grasping for air. I made a new word, grasping.\"\n\nPaul and Perry are far from a circus.\n\nThe bout will take place as the main event of a nine-fight card contested across eight, three-minute rounds using traditional boxing rules. Both men are required to meet the 200-pound weight limit.\n\nThe pay-per-view broadcast gets underway at 8 p.m. ET/5 p.m. PT and can be purchased through multiple platforms, including DAZN, PPV.com and inDemand.\n\nA fight with Perry is anything but a tune-up for the 27-year-old ex-YouTuber. But practically speaking, the squared circle is Paul's arena of choice. Barring fatigue, flat-footedness, or an apparent injury, Paul should be able to use his crisp strikes to land the KO shot and punch (literally and figuratively) a ticket to the anticipated date with Mike Tyson on November 15 in Arlington, Texas.", "source": {"uri": "deadspin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Deadspin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8232118810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "16:19:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T16:19:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T16:19:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/brianmazique/2024/07/18/jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-date-time-and-how-to-watch/", "title": "Jake Paul Vs. Mike Perry: Date, Time And How To Watch", "body": "Jake Paul climbs back into the boxing ring on Saturday, July 20, in Tampa, FL, at the Amalie Arena. Paul will take on former UFC fighter and BKFC star Platinum Mike Perry.\n\nPerry replaced Mike Tyson, who was originally scheduled to face Paul at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, TX, in what would be Netflix's first-ever live sports event.\n\nTyson became ill, and the fight with Paul was postponed until November, but to keep the date intact, the pivot was to Perry as an opponent.\n\nBefore we talk a bit more about Paul's latest boxing challenge, here is a look at all the pertinent viewing information you'll need to catch the event.\n\nThe 32-year-old from Orlando is no stranger to combat sports. He has a 14-8 record in MMA. He has a perfect 5-0 record in bare-knuckle boxing with wins over Eddie Alvarez, Luke Rockhold, Thiago Alves, and Michael \"Venom\" Page. He's had one professional boxing match back in 2015.\n\nThat one didn't end well, as Perry was knocked out in the fourth round.\n\nAs a draw, Perry is as tough as they come. He seemingly lives to fight, and he brings an edge to him that could be great for the PPV sales of the fight.\n\nBeing relatively local to the Tampa area could also help to boost ticket sales.\n\nWhile Paul is headed for his scrap with Perry, he has never taken his eye off the fight with Tyson. Despite the age gap, Paul remains focused on getting that massive fight done and making history on Netflix.\n\nDespite Paul's relative inexperience, he may prove to have better technical skill with the sweet science than Perry possesses.\n\nThe fight should be entertaining, but Perry will need to wear Paul down or catch him with a big shot to create the level of havoc necessary to claim victory.\n\nThe Puerto Rican queen, Serrano, also makes her return to the boxing ring. Initially, she was set to rematch Katie Taylor in the co-main event of the Paul-Tyson clash.\n\nWith that massive event on pause, Serrano will stay active, but she will be facing a lesser-known opponent in Stevie Morgan.\n\nSerrano must escape without much issue or injury if she hopes to secure another opportunity to get the best of Taylor.\n\nThe latter won their first meeting by split decision in April 2022. The meeting with Taylor has been rescheduled as the co-main event for Paul-Tyson in November, but there is at least some pressure on Serrano to beat Morgan to keep the rematch with Taylor {"uri": "8234867032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "11:00:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T11:00:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T11:00:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10128749-jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-fight-odds-live-stream-predictions", "title": "Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry: Fight Odds, Live Stream, Predictions", "body": "Jake Paul in his last bout with Ryan BourlandAl Bello/Getty Images\n\nJake Paul already has UFC stars, YouTubers and a slam dunk champion on his resume. He'll try to add a bare-knuckle boxing star in Mike Perry to his resume on Saturday night in Tampa, Florida.\n\nOf course, Perry isn't the \"Mike\" that everyone was hoping to see Paul see in the ring. This was originally the date for a highly anticipated tussle with boxing legend Mike Tyson. However, the 58-year-old was forced to postpone the match on the advice of medical experts after an ulcer flare up.\n\nThat bout is now set up for November 15.\n\nStill, for those who enjoy tuning in to Paul's boxing career, this might be a stiffer test than he has seen recently. Perry had a middling record during his time in UFC, but he's found his niche as a bare-knuckle boxer with wins over UFC veterans Luke Rockhold, Eddie Alvarez and Thiago Alves.\n\nThis fight will take place under traditional boxing rules with gloves, but there's some intrigue as to how Paul will handle Perry's aggression. Here's a look at all the info you need to catch the bout.\n\nFight Info and Odds\n\nWhen: Saturday, July 20 at 9 p.m. ET (main event ringwalks approximately midnight ET)\n\nAt this point, Paul's earned at least enough respect to be the favorite against most non-boxers. Wins over Ben Askren and Tyron Woodley weren't as impressive because they were both more grapplers in their MMA glory days, but wins over Anderson Silva and Nate Diaz proved he could beat most people who are merely trying their hand at professional boxing.\n\nThat brings us to Perry.\n\nPerry was a stand-and-bang MMA fighter who has found that his approach to striking has generally worked in the bare-knuckle boxing arena. The problem is that there are major differences between the two sports.\n\nFor one, it's a lot easier to defend punches wearing full-size gloves. Thus, the sweet science is a bit more tactical and relies more on technique and nuance.\n\nThat's not a specialty for Perry. His aggression and willingness to stand and trade are his best assets. It's a different skillset than Paul has really seen in the ring, but it's also one that doesn't necessarily bode well for Perry.\n\nOne psychological component to consider is that Perry doesn't have much to lose here. This is a quick detour from his recent successful run in bare-knuckle boxing. A loss here isn't going to cost him much as he continues to be a star of the BKFC organization.\n\nPaul, however, has a lot on the line here. Perry is not considered an actual boxer and he has a huge payday coming up with Tyson in November.\n\nIf Paul can't take care of business in an emphatic way here, it's a loss for The Problem Child.\n\nPrediction\n\nNot only is Paul the better pure boxer, but he also has a massive size advantage. That has been true in more than one of his fights and he's shown the ability to take advantage of it.\n\nWhile Paul has a long ways to go if he truly wants to become a world champion-caliber boxer, he already possesses more skills than Perry. There is danger in this fight. Perry's aggression and power could cause problems if Paul isn't prepared with ways to mitigate it.\n\nBut the reality is that Paul is bigger, stronger and more skilled. Initially Paul was supposed to fight Mike Tyson, but Tyson unfortunately had to postpone due to a medical emergency.\n\nThese two will face off in Tampa Bay at Amalie Arena, with the start time set for 9 p.m. ET and the main event will start around 12 a.m. ET. Unsurprisingly, Paul is the heavy favorite according to the sportsbooks.\n\nJake Paul vs. Mike Perry Odds\n\nAs you can see, the odds on Paul range from -420 to -500 to win straight up, which give him roughly a 80% chance to win. Paul has fought in 10 boxing matches and is 9-1 in those fights, with his one loss coming to Tommy Fury. Fury, ironically enough, is similar to Paul in that he is a former social media influencer who has turned his sights on becoming a professional boxer. While Paul's 9-1 record looks impressive, he has yet to face a ranked professional.\n\nMike Perry, meanwhile, is a former UFC and BKFC (Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship) fighter, with an MMA record of 14-8 with 11 knockouts. He has only boxed once in his career and that was back in 2015, and he lost his lone boxing match as well. So, while Perry has significant experience with the UFC and BKFC, this will only be his second professional boxing match, which goes into why Paul is so heavily favored.\n\nJake Paul vs. Mike Perry Prediction\n\nWhile it is not exactly a bold prediction to say that Paul wins, there also is not much value at any of the books. With that said, the under 7.5 is also a play at more reasonable odds of -205 at DraftKings. As this is an eight round boxing match, essentially the bet here is that this fight does not go the full distance.\n\nAccording to DraftKings, the most likely scenario is that Paul wins by a KO/TKO/DQ This eight-round cruiserweight boxing bout is set to take place at the Amalie Arena in Tampa, Florida, on Saturday, July 20th.\n\nPaul's highly anticipated fight that was scheduled this weekend against the legendary Mike Tyson at the AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, has been postponed. This unexpected change is due to Tyson's health issues, specifically a flare-up of an ulcer. As a result, the fight has been rescheduled for November 15.\n\nNow Paul, with a 9-1 record and six knockouts, will be stepping into the ring with Perry, who has a 0-1 record, in a boxing match that he said will prepare him for Tyson.\n\nHere are the walkout times for the \"Fear No Man\" main event between Paul vs. Perry.\n\nWhen will Mike Tyson fight Jake Paul? He wants the credibility for boxing, but he's not actually willing to take a proper fight in boxing. {"uri": "8232022986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "15:14:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T15:14:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T15:13:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/boxing/2024/07/18/669926adca47418a628b45b3.html", "title": "Mike Perry gets fed up with provocations and takes down Jake Paul's mascot", "body": "Boxing. Paul was able to get to safety behind the ropes as Perry yelled at him in disgust.\n\nAt the post-event press conference, Perry sported a tacky chain with Jake Paul's badly injured head dangling from his neck. while Perry's win is at +300, which means that for the same $100 the bet gives a return of $300.\n\nThe draw pays +1200, the odds for a knockout in favor of Paul is -125, which improves to $80 profit {"uri": "8235060008", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "14:02:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T14:02:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T14:02:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.mmafighting.com/2024/7/20/24198419/mike-perry-recounts-past-sparring-session-jake-paul-doesnt-expect-to-get-much-credit-for-beating-him", "title": "Mike Perry doesn't expect to get much credit for beating Jake Paul, but 'I'm going to give Jake a nose job'", "body": "There's a common saying in combat sports that what happens in the gym, stays in the gym.\n\nHowever, that's becoming less and less common these days as teammates and sparring partners end up fighting each other on a much more regular basis, which usually means past private training sessions become very public. That's the case with Mike Perry and Jake Paul, who actually only sparred together for six rounds several years ago, but that session has become the stuff of legends, especially as they prepared to fight on Saturday.\n\nFor Paul, sparring a savage like Perry gave him the confidence that he was making the right choice to go from social media influencer to boxing enthusiast. Meanwhile, Perry was admittedly impressed by what he saw out of Paul that day, even if he doesn't spend much time dwelling on it all these years later.\n\nThat being said, Perry knew that sparring Paul in the past was going to come up constantly after he replaced Mike Tyson in the fight coming up on July 20.\n\n\"Let them do it,\" Perry told MMA Fighting about the narrative built around that sparring session. \"It's a good reason for both of us to fight each other. It was a seed I planted long ago when I told him I didn't want his little paycheck for showing up to spar, that happened after we sparred.\n\n\"When they told me going into the sixth, 'This would be the last round Mike,' I was like, 'OK, I thought he had an eight-round fight? Should we do eight rounds?' The gap was closing on him. The 'Platinum' pressure builds up over time.\"\n\nPerry recounted one particular moment during that session when he realized Paul was learning and adapting on the job, which was something he didn't expect when they first started throwing hands.\n\nAs a veteran with far more fight experience on his r\u00e9sum\u00e9, Perry also made some necessary changes to then turn the tables on Paul.\n\n\"I remember from when I sparred Jake, the first 20 seconds of the sparring way back in the day, I came out with this good combination I had back then where I [throw] the one-two and then I throw the three [hook] to the body and, boom, I caught him,\" Perry said. \"Left hook to the liver. Twenty seconds in he [grimaces] and goes, 'Good shot, it was a good body shot.' I kind of lightened up a little bit, and then boom, he kind of hit me with some of those sniper shots from the outside. I'm like, 'OK, time to pick it back up.'\n\n\"I give him credit because he adjusted and I wasn't able to get that body shot back in on him that day. I remember that. So I understand that he's going to adjust to some things.\"\n\nThat sparring session happened when Perry was still a UFC fighter, so he was nowhere near the boxer he is today after turning his full attention to bare-knuckle boxing over the past few years. He has since also scored a win over veteran boxer Michael Seals in 2021 in an adjusted rule set for Triad Combat.\n\nThere's little doubt that Paul has evolved as well, which is why Perry is expecting the unexpected when they meet again on Saturday.\n\n\"He might start slow,\" Perry said. \"He might get better as the fight goes on. He might try to carry his weight or put it on me. I expect him to have no choice but to run because I'm the smaller guy. I'll cut the short angles, I'll slip side to side and take the angle around him and give him the old reach-around like he said he would give to me.\"\n\nAhead of the fight, Paul has continuously touted himself as a future champion, but his r\u00e9sum\u00e9 as a boxer still faces constant criticism. The only opponent on his record with equal size, age, and skill counts as Paul's only loss against Tommy Fury by split decision in 2023.\n\nPrior to the Perry matchup getting booked, Paul was supposed to face Tyson, who was a ferocious heavyweight champion in his day but also just celebrated his 58th birthday.\n\nPaul has largely decorated his record with fights against UFC veterans such as Nate Diaz, Anderson Silva, and Tyron Woodley, with his past two wins coming against journeymen boxers who both got obliterated inside the first round.\n\nDespite entering this fight as the underdog, Perry expects all of those factors from Paul's past to rob him of the praise he should receive with a win, but he knows just how much this fight means to him.\n\n\"When I beat him, they're going to take it away from me,\" Perry said. \"They're going to say, 'We knew it, Jake wasn't ready for an opponent like this,' but you've got to look at the stats. I'm 0-1 as a pro boxer. Yes, I have about 30 professional fights, so I had so much success in the MMA world and now bare-knuckle boxing. People aren't giving bare-knuckle boxing the credit it deserves.\n\n\"But Jake is 9-1 in pro boxing and he's fought about two or three real fighters. I think experience, everything here is lined up perfectly. I'm going to give Jake a nose job.\"", "source": {"uri": "mmafighting.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MMA Fighting"}, "authors": [{"uri": "damon_martin@mmafighting.com", "name": "Damon Martin",
