{"uri": "8235151168", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:34:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:34:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:34:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://stpetecatalyst.com/jake-pauls-boxing-bonanza-showcases-hometown-hero/", "title": "Jake Paul's boxing bonanza showcases hometown hero", "body": "Mike \"Platinum\" Perry, the latest non-traditional boxer set to meet Jake Paul in the ring, believes he is defending his backyard tonight at Amalie Arena.\n\nThe Orlando resident split time between Flint, Michigan and Central Florida during a troubled childhood. The undefeated bare-knuckle champion and former mixed martial arts (MMA) star will headline the \"Fear No Man\" promotion with Paul, the former child actor-turned-professional YouTuber who is controversially now the face of boxing.\n\nHowever, the co-main event features a Tampa native, Stevie \"Sledgehammer\" Morgan. The Gaither High School graduate will attempt to dethrone top-ranked women's boxing pioneer Amanda \"The Real Deal\" Serrano.\n\n\"I was just talking to my coach about this - every fighter's dream is to have a big fight like this in your hometown,\" Morgan told the Catalyst. \"That's like the top of the mountain. So, it means a lot.\"\n\nFans of the \"sweet science\" will also appreciate marque boxing returning to Tampa Bay. The area's last big event featured Jake Paul defeating former Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) star Tyron Woodley, in December 2021.\n\nMorgan expects to have a large contingent in her corner. The local underdog will need that support against one of the best pound-for-pound boxers in the sport's history.\n\nMorgan was a 23-year-old single mother in 2014 when she launched \"Cater Me Fit,\" a meal delivery service. The business grew to include over 30 employees, and the woman now known as Sledgehammer garnered local praise for her entrepreneurialism.\n\nA multi-sport athlete at Gaither, Morgan began focusing on boxing full-time after the pandemic decimated her business. She turned pro in 2022 and quickly moved up the ranks with her ambidextrous power.\n\n\"My team had a plan for me from the beginning,\" Morgan said. \"My job was just to work hard and listen and follow the plan, and that's what has got me into this position.\"\n\nThat position is near-top billing on a stacked card that will cost fans $69 to stream on DAZN pay-per-view. Morgan (14-1, 13 KOs) has fought six times since October, winning every one via first-round knockout.\n\nSerrano (46-21, 30 KOs) is an undisputed champ with nine world titles in seven weight classes. Morgan has compared the fight to a \"real-life Rocky-Apollo Creed movie.\"\n\nWhile she is still relatively unknown, the sport's various governing bodies include Morgan in their Top 10 rankings. She said a victory in front of her home crowd \"will do everything for my career.\"\n\n\"This is what we do it for,\" Morgan added. \"You want to compete against the best. There was no hesitation. I've been waiting for an opportunity, preparing for an opportunity like this since day one.\"\n\nShe also noted the event's local impact. Champion boxers like St. Petersburg's Winky Wright, Jeff \"Left Hook\" Lacy and Tampa's Antonio Tarver represented the region throughout the early-to-mid-2000s. \"I hope I can be added to that list,\" Morgan said.\n\nShe said a lack of opportunities and exposure impedes a \"ton of talent\" in Tampa Bay. However, Morgan believes Most Valuable Promotions (MVP), the event's organizers, can uplift the local boxing community like it has in Orlando.\n\nPaul, who co-founded MVP, also has local ties. Tampa-based Venture firm Florida Funders invested in his sports betting app, Betr, for the fifth time in March.\n\nTampaBay.Ventures, another local investment firm, participated in Betr's initial funding rounds. Paul was initially scheduled to face Mike Tyson in Dallas as part of a Netflix special tonight, but pivoted when the 58-year-old boxing legend postponed the fight until November due to health issues.\n\nThe controversial Paul will now face a much younger opponent who recently told the \"Problem Child\" he would \"dig through your eyeballs and find your memories.\" In a separate interview, Perry noted that \"people have been waiting to see him get beat up.\"\n\n\"I've been knocking down champions, and so has he, so we both earned this spot and limelight we're going to be in,\" Perry added. \"I bring the heat when I fight, so I think it will be something everyone can enjoy.\n\n\"It's not as brutal as bare-knuckle - there might not be as much blood. I'm going to try, though. I'm going to try to make him bleed.\"\n\nAfter flaming out as a mixed martial artist, Perry has resurrected his combat sports career in the Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship (BKFC). Unlike other former UFC fighters Paul has faced in the ring, Perry has always fought better on his feet and remains in his prime.\n\nYahoo Sports recently noted that Perry, the self-proclaimed \"king of violence,\" approaches fights as if his \"only goal is blood on the floor - and he's not too particular about whose it is.\"\n\nPerry (5-0, 3KOs BKFC) now considers himself a \"Florida boy.\" He named his son Ocean due to his affinity for the water and credited the sunshine, \"Latinas\" and \"living free\" for his permanent relocation.\n\n\"I'm just looking forward to putting on a good fight here as a local,\" Perry said. \"I don't think he's (Paul) fought someone with the power and pressure I'm going to bring.\"\n\nPerry has earned several accolades since eschewing gloves and hopes his performance Saturday night uplifts the BKFC. The event's top fighters will likely earn over a million dollars, although Perry insists the fight is more than a payday.\n\n\"I'm looking to disrespect Jake (Paul) all night long at Amalie Arena,\" he said. \"I want to disrespect this kid all over the ring.\"\n\nTickets range from around $40 to nearly $6,000. Before Jake Paul Fight", "body": "'Platinum' Mike Perry I'm Launching My Own Combat Sports Organization! ... Announces Night Before Jake Paul Fight\n\nMike Perry will be across from Jake Paul in just over 24 hours (more on that in a minute), but before fight night Platinum made a huge announcement, telling us he's launching his very own combat sports promotion, Dirty Boxing Championship!\n\n\"We are friends for fighters and fans,\" 32-year-old Perry told Babcock on the TMZ Sports TV show (airs nightly on FS1).\n\n\"Me and my team have been working on this for quite some time,\" Mike added. \"We've tried to hint at this, we've been making way and we're ready to make the announcement that this is coming very soon. We're very close to being sanctioned by commissions and we're ready to get some athletes and get a card together and put a fight on sometime this year.\"\n\nWhat will DBC look like? {"uri": "8233892997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:05:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:05:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:04:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://talksport.com/sport/931765/jake-paul-record-next-fight-mike-perry-mike-tyson-tommy-fury/", "title": "Jake Paul next fight and record: American set for huge Mike Tyson clash", "body": "Jake Paul is one of the biggest names on the influencer boxing scene, and he's planning a big 2024.\n\nThe controversial YouTuber, aka 'The Problem Child' has two fights lined up across the rest of the year, as he looks to continue his boxing career.\n\nSince the YouTuber-turned-boxer made his professional debut, he has blown away most of his opponents.\n\nHe is fast becoming a huge name in the sport, and with Mike Tyson in his sights, talkSPORT.com has looked into Paul's career so far and who he's facing next.\n\nPaul started his professional career by knocking out a fellow YouTuber in Miami back in January 2020.\n\nThe American floored his UK social media foe Gib three times in the opener, causing the referee to stop the obvious mismatch.\n\nFew predicted just how one-sided the bout would turn out to be, with Gib having previously won his two white collar contests.\n\nPaul next knocked out former NBA star Robinson in the second round of a rather bizarre fight in November 2020.\n\nThe ex-Vine star settled his feud with the NBA great on the undercard of Mike Tyson's comeback exhibition against Roy Jones Jr.\n\nPaul scored his first knockdown in the first round before he sent Robinson to the canvas twice more following several devastating right hands.\n\nPaul made light work of another UFC star by knocking Ben Askren out in the first round of their fight.\n\nThe former Disney Channel actor flattened ex-welterweight Askren with a right hand inside the opening two minutes to claim an emphatic victory.\n\nA nice jab set-up Paul's overhand right and despite Askren getting up, the referee called it day with 'Funky' looking unsteady on his feet.\n\nPaul's toughest fight to that point was his first showdown against Woodley in Cleveland as he went the distance for the first time in his career.\n\nHe secured the win by split decision and couldn't hide his delight after winning 77-75, 75-77, 78-74 on the scorecards.\n\nPaul's second bout with Woodley more straight forward as he knocked out the 40-year-old with one punch in their rematch.\n\nPaul then beat Anderson Silva by unanimous decision in their exhibition fight in the USA.\n\nThe 25-year-old maintained his flawless professional record against the UFC legend, moving to 6-0, with the judges giving scores of 77-74, 78-73 and 78-73.\n\nThis was Paul's toughest fight to date and after a hard-fought six rounds, he made his statement in the seventh.\n\nHe knocked down Silva with a strong right hand, winning the final round which ended up proving to be all-important.\n\nNext came his first career defeat to Tommy Fury in early 2023.\n\nAfter months of digs and barbs, the Brit and the American finally met in Saudi Arabia.\n\nPaul knocked Fury down in the eighth round, but Tyson Fury's half-brother won via a split decision, with the judges scoring the contest 76-73, 76-73 and 74-75 in favour of the Brit.\n\nThis put Paul on 6-1, and was a serious setback.\n\nHowever, he's bounced back and has won his last three fights comprehensively.\n\nNext up was UFC legend Nate Diaz.\n\nThe American elected not to extend his UFC contract in 2022, and he moved into boxing.\n\nPaul stepped into the ring just three months after his defeat to Fury and won via unanimous decision.\n\nIn truth, it wasn't close as the judges scored it 97-92, 98-91 and 98-91.\n\nBut The Problem Child wasn't done there for 2023 as he faced a third different opponent of the year in Andre August.\n\nAugust was an unknown professional boxer, but he was viciously knocked out by Paul inside the first round.\n\nThe end came when Paul followed a left-handed jab with a brutal uppercut that floored his opponent.\n\nPaul's most recent fight came in March 2024 against Ryan Bourland.\n\nAgain, his opponent proved to be no match as he recorded a first-round TKO.\n\nBourland offered little resistance as Paul laid into him for a full minute before the referee waved it off.\n\nOf the ten professional fights Paul has competed in, he's won nine with one defeat.\n\nHe has claimed six victories via knockout or TKO.\n\nAhead of his comfortable win over Bourland, Paul weighed in at 199.8lbs, and despite an early scare, he's hit weight at 200lbs for his next fight.\n\nThe 27-year-old stands at 6ft 1 [185cm] and has a reach of 76in [193cm].\n\nPaul was meant to face Mike Tyson next, but the former undiputed heavyweight champion of the world had to pull out due to medical concerns.\n\nAs a result, Mike Perry has stepped in.\n\nThis will be just his second professional boxing match, and it's set to take place on Saturday, July 20.\n\nShould Paul come through that, the long-awaited bout with Tyson has been scheduled for later in the year.\n\nShould there be no further delays, that fight will take place on Friday, November 15.\n\nIt is set to be held the 80,000-capacity AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas and will be streamed on Netflix.\n\nPaul sees nothing but an easy KO against Perry.\n\nSpeaking ahead of the bout, he said: \"You're going to smell good when you get knocked the f*** out,\" he told his opponent. \"Two rounds, max. I mean, two rounds max.\n\n\"Let's be honest, brother. He's just not a boxer. I've elevated to such a high level. People haven't even seen my ability over the last year because I've gotten first-round knockouts.\n\n\"There's no film, there's nothing people can study out there for him to prepare for what I'm going to bring to the table.\n\n\"I'm just too sharp, too clean, I punch way too hard, power in both hands and he makes a lot of mistakes. There's nothing he can do.\n\n\"I respect him. He's very violent. It's not taking away from Mike Perry. {"uri": "8233932853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:37:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:37:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:36:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://bloodyelbow.com/2024/07/19/jake-paul-needs-the-towel-to-make-200lb-limit-at-second-time-of-asking-as-mike-perry-fight-is-made-official/", "title": "Jake Paul needs the towel to make 200lb limit at second time of asking as Mike Perry fight is made official", "body": "Jake Paul needed to strip down behind a towel in order to make a carer-highest weight for his fight with Mike Perry tomorrow night.\n\nThe social media star has previously fought as low as just under 184lb, but was bulking up for a bout with Mike Tyson that was set for this weekend and postponed to November. Instead, he has opted to stay busy by facing the bare-knuckle boxing star, who used to compete at 170lb in the UFC.\n\nPaul reportedly had to get his weight down from 230lb at his peak during camp for the Tyson fight in order to make his way down to cruiserweight. And he just about completed the task this morning in order to accurately tip the scales.\n\nDuring this morning's early weigh-ins, Jake Paul headed to the scales accompanied by a large entourage. The then stepped on in just a pair of black shorts emblazoned with the logo for his new personal care brand 'W'.\n\nHe came in at an initial check weight of 200.2lb, which was misinterpreted by some as him missing weight at the first time of asking. However, when he returned to the scale without his shorts, he was declared to be 200lb even, meaning he made weight for the fight.\n\nPaul proceeded to celebrate making weight with what has become a routine at this point; declaring that he is 'fully dialled' and asking media 'you like that?' The latter is an homage to Atlanta Falcons quarter-back Kirk Cousins.\n\nIn the meantime, the much smaller Mike Perry appeared in great spirits as he came in looking healthy at a career-highest 196.6lb. It's almost 30lb heavier than his boxing debut in 2015 against Kenneth McNeil, and more than 12lb over his last BKFC weigh-in when he faced Thiago Alves in April.\n\nAfter the postponement of Paul vs Tyson, the YouTuber-turned-boxer insisted that he stay busy and continue to fight on July 20 as planned. In the days following their announcement of a new November 15 date, his team at Most Valuable Promotions put together this weekend's bout with Perry.\n\nHowever, one key issue was a weight class, with the former welterweight likely only able to keep his weight as high as cruiserweight. They opted for cruiserweight, which meant that Paul had to make a relatively quick cut to the new limit.\n\nHis former coach Shane Mosley had claimed that in order to compete at heavyweight with Tyson, Paul had ballooned to around 230lb. This was later confirmed, meaning that he had to cut 30lb in order to make weight for the showdown with Perry.\n\nShould he get through tomorrow night's bout as expected, all eyes will be on November 15 and the AT&T Stadium in Texas. Paul will face former world heavyweight champion Tyson at the massive venue, with the bout serving as the first live boxing fight on Netflix.\n\n\"A lot of people think I'm crazy for pivoting to this,\" Paul told DAZN. \"Why Mike Perry, why now, why take the risk, you could lose the biggest payday of your life against Mike Tyson if you lose to Mike Perry who is a violent killer, a bare-knuckle, undefeated legend over there.\"\n\nHe reiterated that idea during an appearance on The Pat McAfee Show this week, and defended Tyson continuing to fight deep into his 50s. \"I view it as, say it to Mike Tyson's face and see what he does to you,\" Paul explained.\n\n\"The one reporter who was discrediting him, he was about to jump over the press conference table and beat the dude's a**. We aren't Mike Tyson's dad. We don't control Mike Tyson. He's his own boss.\n\n\"If he wants to go in there and make tens of millions of dollars, and potentially end my run, then who are we to stop him? This guy has been doing this his whole entire life. {"uri": "8234551045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "06:00:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T06:00:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T05:59:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/boxing-news-chupapi-influencer-labeled-annoying-after-mike-perry-nearly-puts-him-to-sleep-for-shouting-in-his-ear/", "title": "Chupapi Influencer Labeled 'Annoying' After Mike Perry Nearly Puts Him to Sleep for Shouting in His Ear", "body": "Tiktok star Jay Ferrer, aka @jaykindafunny8, did not think of the consequences when he decided to play a prank on Mike Perry. Perry, who will be taking on Jake Paul this weekend in his second-ever professional boxing bout, seems quite confident of his chances. At the same time, some fans are pretty vocal about their support for Paul, although the 'Chupapi influencer' took things a bit too far.\n\nFor the uninitiated, \"Chupapi Munyayo\" or \"Chupapi Mu\u00f1a\u00f1yo\" is a phrase popularised by Ferrer. The phrase itself is essentially gibberish and doesn't have a specific meaning in any language. Ferrer usually uses this term when he sneaks up on people and yells this into their ears.\n\nThe Tiktoker carried out the same prank on an unsuspecting Mike Perry who was standing backstage. Ferrer snuck up on the boxer from behind and yelled into his ear that Jake Paul would win. Startled, Perry turned around and pushed the Tiktoker away, before the BKFC star's security team kicked him out of the premises.\n\nHowever, the scenario could have played out very differently had Perry not taken so kindly to the prank, and it did not take long for the video to go viral on social media. Naturally, people loved how the MMA star put Ferrer in his place and poured in with some hilarious reactions.\n\n\"How do people find this funny? Like it would have been funny if Mike hit him with a right hand\"- commented a fan praising Perry's restraint.\n\nAnother fan added, \"This social media influencers need to learn respect.\"\n\nInterestingly, while Perry tried to keep his cool during his altercation with the Tiktok star, his final face-off against Paul was the complete opposite.\n\nThe final face-off between Perry and Paul got extremely heated as the two men did not go easy on the trash talk. Perry insisted that he was coming to take off Paul's head and had nothing but violence in store for the 27-year-old.\n\nSurprisingly, Paul chose a different route of attack as he bashed Conor McGregor and other MMA Fighters. He taunted Perry, claiming that all MMA artists were horrible boxers and he could not wait to put another one in his place this weekend.\n\nEven though security had to step in soon after following a {"uri": "8234154198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "21:13:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T21:13:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T21:13:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.mmamania.com/2024/7/19/24198906/following-the-money-jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-betting-line-movements-tracker", "title": "Following the money: Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry betting line movements tracker", "body": "Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry goes down this weekend (Sat., July 20, 2024) inside Amalie Arena in Tampa, Fla., streaming live on DAZN pay-per-view (PPV). This event was supposed to see Paul taking on Mike Tyson. Unfortunately (?) \"Iron\" Mike suffered a medical emergency, forcing him to withdraw from the contest. The pair are supposed to resume hostilities in November (I wouldn't bet on that happening, though).\n\n\"Platinum\" Perry is the man who has been selected to fill in for the former Heavyweight champ. Perry was a long-time UFC Welterweight who has since found his groove in bareknuckle boxing (lighting up Thiago Alves in BKFC most recently).\n\nLet's checkout the money lines on \"Paul vs. Perry\" and most of the other bouts on the card\n\n...\n\nThe odds on this bout have grown quite a lot since opening. Initially we had Jake Paul as a -250 favorite and Mike Perry as a +200 underdog (per Pro Boxing Odds). With Paul's odds shortening to -428 it's clear that the public thinks that initial price was too high and that Paul is likely to get the win over his short notice replacement.\n\nIt's hard to know whether the betting public that follows Paul fights are knowledgeable or not, though. There might be a lot of 'fan money' flowing his way, with Gen Zs convinced the man they follow on Tik Tok will beat anyone who is put in front of him.\n\nWe've seen this kind of line movement with Paul before. In both of his recent squash matches his line decreased by between 5 and 7 percent. Against both Tommy Fury and Anderson Silva Paul's line decreased by 7.7 and 10.6% with him closing as a slight favorite in those bouts. Against Nate Diaz his odds actually rose by 1.7% to see him close as a -400 favorite.\n\nI personally think Paul will win this bout, so I understand a lot of folks jumping on that -250 line. I think -400 is a little too short for this bout, though. I can see a path to victory for Perry, where he's able to pressure Paul into mistakes and frustrate him with all his activity. However, I do think that, ultimately, the most likely outcome is Paul plays keep-away with his chin, using his reach advantage, and pot shots his way to a boring decision.\n\nAmanda Serrano is a massive favorite here against Stevie Morgan. Morgan doesn't have the skill or experience to pose a serious test to Serrano, who is taking an easy assignment to stay busy while she waits to try and avenge her loss to Kate Taylor. These lines have barely moved because neither are enticing enough for the public to put money down on. Serrano is so certain to win that Vegas have basically taken her off the table for most betters. Morgan's +1600 looks nice on paper, but her odds are only that high because she stands no chance in this match-up.\n\nThe only shift of note in this line happened on July 17 when Serrano's odds suddenly dipped to -4286 and then popped up to -3871),\n\nAshton Sylve is a decent sized favorite in this match-up. Sylve belongs to Paul's Most Valuable Promotions and he has been given a platform, both in the ring and on social media, to make himself a star with those who follow 'influencer boxing'. To his credit, he's more boxer than influencer and he has some decent skills, as proven by his fantastic body shot TKO in his last bout. Lucas Baldi is a solid pro and the biggest test Sylve has faced. However, he's on the wrong side of 30 and he likely won't be able to keep up with the speedy Sylve. As you can see by the line movement, the public felt Vegas had it just right with their opening line.\n\nTony Aguilar and Corey Marksman fought to a draw in February. Marksman is the more powerful puncher and he was able to land the hardest punches in his first fight with Aguilar. He came on strong late in the fight after Aguilar took a number of the early rounds. The public must have felt Marksman was a little short changed on the draw decision in February. There has been a steady flow of money pushing him from a -170 favorite to a -225 favorite. I agree with the public that Marksman is a worthy favorite in this bout and he should be too technical for Aguilar in their second meeting.\n\nJulio Cesar Chavez Jr. opened as a -215 favorite and the public seems to think he deserves shorter odds than that. Money on the former WBC Middleweight champ has shortened his odds by around 10%. Uriah Hall opened as +170 and those have grown by almost 20%.\n\nI can understand why the public might be fading Hall. He's an aging MMA vet who looked just OK in his only pro boxing bout to date -- a ho-hum decision win over former NFL running back La'Veon Bell. Hall is also coming in on short notice.\n\nHowever, Chavez Jr. might be someone who fights down to his opponent, like he did when Anderson Silva beat him in 2021. Chavez Jr. has had an awful 2024 so far, too. He's been arrested for possessing an illegal assault rifle (after a 911 caller told police he might be a danger to himself) and he's had a stint in rehab for drugs and alcohol use. He's also been embroiled in a bitter feud with his Boxing Hall of Fame father Julio Cesar Chavez Sr. The younger Chavez has accused his dad for beating his mother and conspiring to kill him.\n\nGiven all these distractions I'm happy to take a chance on Hall getting the upset here.\n\nThe biggest line movement for this card features Mike Perry, whose opening odds of +200 have ballooned to +338. Perry's line may be a victim of Paul's notoriety, with Paul fans flocking to back the vanguard of the influencer boxing movement. Perry will also have a pretty significant size and reach disadvantage against Paul (who has proven a bit of a size bully in his boxing career thus far). If you like Perry in this match-up, you're probably delighted to see his odds grow. It's probably wise to wait a little longer to see if they can go any higher.\n\nIf you like betting on underdogs there aren't many decent opportunities to do that on this card. My favorite dog is Uriah Hall. Though he's not as good a boxer as Julio Cesar Chavez Jr., he's not bringing in the same kind of baggage the former WBC Middleweight champ is dragging along with him. If Chavez Jr. doesn't have his mind set on competing he could very well lose to another MMA veteran.\n\nEnough about me, though, which of these underdogs do you like the most?\n\nRemember that MMAmania.com will deliver LIVE round-by-round, blow-by-blow coverage of the entire Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry card right here, starting with YouTube \"Prelims\" matches, which are scheduled to begin at 7 p.m. ET (and right here). The remaining PPV main card will air on DAZN at 9 p.m. ET.\n\nTo check out the latest and greatest \"Paul vs. Perry\" news and notes be sure to hit up our comprehensive event archive right here.", {"uri": "8232238816", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "17:53:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T17:53:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T17:53:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.totalprosports.com/boxing/who-did-jake-paul-lose-his-undefeated-boxing-record-to/", "title": "Who Did Jake Paul Lose His Undefeated Boxing Record To?", "body": "Jake Paul, the internet celebrity-turned-boxer, put the entire boxing world on notice. He crossed over from making YouTube videos to knocking down opponents in the ring. The younger Paul went on to get a six-fight win streak in boxing. However, February 26, 2023, was a forgettable day for 'The Problem Child.'\n\nPaul's undefeated streak came to an end in a surprising turn of events. This came in the form of none other than Tommy Fury, the half-brother of former heavyweight champion Tyson Fury. Tommy was riding on an 8-fight undefeated streak. Notably, the bout took place in Saudi Arabia, far from Paul's usual stomping grounds.\n\nThe fight was a clash of social media titans turned fighters. Paul had been riding high on a wave of victories against ex-MMA fighters like Anderson Silva and Tyron Woodley. But Fury presented a unique challenge altogether. He was a professional boxer trained to outbox and outpoint his opponents.\n\nThe fight wasn't a knockout spectacle. Instead, it was a closely contested split decision. Fury's boxing pedigree showed as he outmaneuvered Paul for most of the fight. He crowded Paul early, using his movement to avoid the YouTuber's powerful overhand right. Paul, to his credit, didn't go down without a fight. He even scored a knockdown in the eighth round.\n\nBut in the end, two out of three judges favored Fury's performance. Paul's undefeated record was no more. He took the loss with surprising grace. It was a humbling moment for the cocky YouTuber who once hinted at fighting Saul 'Canelo' Alvarez. This loss, however, added a new chapter to Paul's boxing story.\n\nCelebrity boxing has become a new norm in combat sports, and it never fails to entertain. There is a lot of money to be made in these types of fights. Paul is arguably the face of celebrity boxing. He was undefeated until he met Tommy in the ring. Paul, who is known for never backing down, called him out once again.\n\nThis time, Paul's team waved a whopping $20 million offer in Tommy's face. They revealed that Tyson Fury's half-brother was potentially missing out on this massive payday because he was not jumping at the chance for a rematch. And Paul wasn't just offering a boxing rematch. He sweetened the deal with an MMA twist.\n\nThe proposal was that an MMA fight would follow a boxing rematch in the PFL cage if Paul won in the rematch. Paul's business partner, Nakisa Bidarian, laid out the enticing path for Tommy. It could lead to nearly $20 million in guaranteed money. But Fury seemed to be playing hard to get. Paul believed Tommy's team didn't understand the business side of boxing. {"uri": "8233597641", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "13:35:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T13:35:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:34:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.mmamania.com/2024/7/19/24199344/jake-paul-vs-mike-perry-preview-platinum-redeemer-latest-headstone-ufc-cemetery-dazn-boxing", "title": "Jake Paul vs. Mike Perry preview: 'Platinum' redeemer ... or latest headstone in UFC cemetery?", "body": "Former Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) middleweight champion, Anderson Silva, is widely-considered to be one of the greatest mixed martial arts (MMA) fighters of all time, due largely in part to his historic reign as 185-pound champion, complete with a record-setting win streak that has yet to be broken.\n\nNot long after that, \"El Gallo\" floored -- then decisioned -- former UFC welterweight Nate Diaz, who once set a CompuStrike record for beating the ever-loving shit out of Donald Cerrone at UFC 141. Like Silva before him, MMA fans were hoping Diaz would bring an end to Paul's boxing career, which up until that point, was built on a foundation of shopworn UFC fighters like Ben Askren and Tyron Woodley.\n\nBoth were sent back to the clearance rack after violent knockout losses.\n\nThat's why it's getting a little cringey to hear marquee UFC fighters beg for boxing matches. If former cage-fighting megastars like Silva and Diaz -- renowned for their hands -- can't beat a twenty-something social media star, who jumped off the couch and took a celebrity boxing match to keep pace with his brother's combat sports stunts, then what chance does any MMA fighter have in the \"sweet science\" against a battle-tested pugilist?\n\nI thought Francis Ngannou had the answer ... until he didn't.\n\nThere have been exceptions, like Anthony Pettis beating Roy Jones Jr. and Vitor Belfort stopping Evander Holyfield. It's just hard to take those wins seriously when you consider Jones Jr. is 55 and Holyfield is 61. With that in mind, defenders of the MMA faith may have finally found their savior in the form of ex-UFC welterweight Mike Perry, who continues to ply his trade as a bareknuckle boxer for Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship (BKFC).\n\nCall him the uncrowned (and perhaps accidental) \"King\" of violence.\n\nPerry was called up to battle Paul this Sat. night (July 20) on DAZN pay-per-view (PPV) in what \"El Gallo\" is hoping to be a quick warmup for his Mike Tyson fight this November on Netflix. Cart before the horse? Consider that Conor McGregor -- dreaming of a pugilistic payday opposite Manny Pacquiao -- had that same philosophy ahead of his Dustin Poirier fight at UFC 257, only to overlook \"The Diamond\" and get knocked the f -- k out.\n\nMcGregor's attempt to right the ship at UFC 264 ended in disaster.\n\nLet's not gloss over the fact that Perry was a middling UFC fighter who had a tremendous amount of bark (but very little bite) when it came time to perform. It's been seven years since his last knockout inside the cage and following that first-round finish, \"Platinum\" was a dreadful 3-7, dropping four of his last five before hitting the open market.\n\nBKFC, like most other combat sports promotions, helped build its brand with fighters who were no longer successful (or no longer wanted) inside the Octagon. With the exception of Michael Page, all of Perry's BKFC wins featured UFC leftovers coming off losses, like Luke Rockhold and Eddie Alvarez, among others. Perry is still relatively young at 32 and let's face it, some of his much-older opponents just wanted a quick paycheck.\n\nJake Paul is 27 years old and takes his boxing career seriously, even if you don't.\n\nThat might be one of many reasons why the combat sports community is so disgusted by Paul. He's only here because of his social media fame, and successful \"influencers\" are widely-regarded as opportunists who didn't pay their dues. I'm sure it's hard for aging MMA fighters who bodysurfed waves of their own blood just for a chance to compete under the UFC banner -- where pay starts as low as $10k per fight -- to watch some cocky YouTube smartass waltz in and score beaucoup bucks.\n\nWhat are they doing wrong?\n\nNothing, per se, but it's time to accept the fighting landscape has changed and it may be more uneven now than it ever was, thanks to new (and sometimes obnoxious) paths to stardom. The MMA industry remains insecure as a whole, which is understandable when you consider how long it took for \"cock fighters\" to be seen as legitimate athletes -- not muscled-up \"skinheads and homosexuals.\"\n\nIt wasn't that long ago when UFC was banned in New York.\n\nThat's why the presence of Paul and his many antics can seem threatening to MMA. Fighting is a serious endeavor and carries a very real danger of death and serious injury. There's also the respect factor, which can sometimes border on parody, but it's no secret that most UFC fighters want to be both feared and admired for their violent attributes.\n\nThat's a pretty tall order when Jake Paul is the face of combat sports.\n\nMaybe Perry will restore order and send \"El Gallo\" back to the YouTube circuit, where he can reignite his feud with longtime rival KSI. The more likely scenario is that Perry, who was knocked out in his one-and-only pro boxing bout, will realize his usual nuke first, collect paychecks later approach doesn't translate well to boxing, where subtly and nuance are still potent weapons in high-stakes prize fights.", "source": {"uri": "mmamania.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MMAmania.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8233360336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:00:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:00:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T10:59:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/mma/jake-paul-tapped-out-mma-33280539", "title": "Jake Paul tapped out in first cage 'fight' as YouTube star plots MMA debut", "body": "Jake Paul found himself tapping to an armbar in the second round of an amateur MMA fight with BJJ black-belt and former Bellator star AJ Agazarm back in 2018, just months before his boxing debut against Deji Olatunji\n\nJake Paul was submitted in an unsanctioned MMA fight months before his debut boxing match with KSI's brother.\n\nThe 27-year-old laced up the 4oz gloves for a training session with BJJ black belt AJ Agazarm in February 2018, before agreeing to face Deji Olatunji that August - and while he would go on to find success in the squared circle, it would be a completely different state of affairs in the octagon.\n\nAt the time, Agazarm was an established name in the world of jiu-jitsu while Paul was a self-admitted YouTuber and vlogger after making the transition from social media site Vine. Paul was 20 years old at the time, with a significant size advantage over his 26-year-old opponent for the day.\n\nThe video came in the form of Paul's first-known footage competing in MMA or boxing, previously having been pictured in high school wrestling tournaments. And while he clearly struggled under Agazarm's constant pressure, he showed fight fans a taste of what was to come in the near future with his 'large and in charge' combinations and angle work.\n\nPaul found himself smothered in the first round of the sparring session, kept at range by AJ before being taken to the ground, mounted and dominated. Helped back to his feet at the end of the round, Paul was breathing heavily and incredibly gassed out, going on to meet his demise in the second.\n\nWhile Paul would find success on the feet, landing a heavy right cross early on, Agazarm was able to shoot for and complete another takedown, make his way into a mount, and submit the YouTuber via a well-executed armbar. Agazarm would sign for Bellator in 2019, building a 3-2 record with the MMA promotion despite losing to Jesse Roberts in his debut.\n\nPaul, meanwhile, would win his amateur boxing debut with Deji with a fifth-round TKO before kicking off a pro career in 2020 with a first-round TKO of fellow YouTuber AnEsonGib. He has built a 9-1 record in the last four years, beating UFC stars Nate Diaz, Ben Askren, Anderson Silva and Tyron Woodley twice - his only loss coming in the form of a narrow split decision loss to Tommy Fury in February 2023.\n\nWhile he was scheduled to take on Mike Tyson this weekend, his 58-year-old boxing great opponent was forced to pull out of the bout earlier this year due to medical concerns, with Paul now set to take on 5-0 BKFC star Mike Perry come July 20 in his toughest test to date. But boxing isn't the only sport that Paul is eyeing up a career in, signing a ground-breaking MMA deal with the Professional Fighters League last January.\n\nSpeaking at the time of the announcement, Paul said: \"I've proven myself in and out of the boxing ring and now I am going to do the same in MMA, and there is no limit to the positive impact I can make on the sport.\" And while Paul is yet to take to the PFL Smart Cage, a rematch under MMA rules with Diaz could still play out in the near future.\n\nPaul and PFL founder Donn Davis offered Diaz a reported $15million for a PFL super-fight this year, only for the Stockton native to take up a boxing match with former UFC foe Jorge Masvidal. Despite Diaz turning down the opportunity to atone for his boxing loss to Paul in the cage, Paul says that he's still open to the bout.\n\nSpeaking at Wednesday's open workout for his upcoming fight with Perry, Paul said: \"Nate Diaz should've taken my $15 million MMA offer, but yesterday's price is not today's price. So now that he needs the money, the offer goes down. {"uri": "2024-07-426306223", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "17:42:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T17:42:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T17:23:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.totalprosports.com/boxing/how-many-knockouts-does-jake-paul-have-in-boxing/", "title": "How Many Knockouts Does Jake Paul Have In Boxing?", "body": "Jake Paul, the YouTube sensation turned boxer, has been making waves in the fight game. Love him or hate him, the fact can't be denied that he's grabbed the boxing world's attention. With his brash personality and surprising skills, Paul has become a polarizing figure in sports.\n\nThe 27-year-old Ohio native first rose to fame through social media platforms. His transition from internet celebrity to professional boxer raised many eyebrows initially. Critics dismissed calling him a gimmick, but Paul has been determined to prove them wrong. Since his professional debut in 2020, he's been steadily building his boxing resume.\n\nPaul has faced a mix of opponents, from fellow YouTubers to former MMA fighters and professional boxers. His dedication to training and improving his craft has been evident with each fight. His professional record stands at 9 wins with just one loss.\n\nJake Paul's Wins Via Knockouts In His Professional Boxing Career\n\nOut of his nine professional wins, six have come by way of a knockout. That's a pretty impressive KO ratio for someone once dismissed as a mere influencer. Paul's first technical knockout victim was fellow YouTuber Ali Eson Gib, aka AnEsonGib, in January 2020. He followed that up by flattening former NBA player Nate Robinson in November 2020.\n\nPaul's most significant TKO came against former MMA champion Ben Askren. In the first round, he sent Askren to the canvas with a thunderous right hand. Askren got up, but the referee stopped the contest. This victory silenced many critics who doubted Paul could hang with \"real\" fighters.\n\nAnother highlight-reel knockout came in his rematch with former UFC champion Tyron Woodley in December 2021. In the first match, Paul won via a split decision. Paul's face-plant punch left Woodley unconscious on the ropes. It was a statement win that proved his first victory over Woodley wasn't a fluke.\n\nAnother KO victory came against Andre August in December 2023. Paul unleashed a vicious uppercut that sent August crashing to the canvas. It was a reminder that 'The Problem Child' carries legitimate power in his hands. His most recent TKO victory was over Ryan Bourland. He stopped him with a flurry of punches in the first round.\n\nJake Paul will next face Mike Perry on July 20, 2024. It will be interesting to see if 'The Problem Child' will claim his seventh win via knockout in Tampa, Florida.", "source": {"uri": "totalprosports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Total Pro {"uri": "8234097849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:13:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:13:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:13:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.entrepreneur.com/business-news/jake-paul-mindset-hacks-mike-tyson-fight-embracing-fear/477304", "title": "Jake Paul Says He's 'Scared' to Fight Mike Tyson, But This Mindset Hack Helps Him 'Embrace' Fear and Make Millions: 'Let It Fuel You'", "body": "At 27 years old, Jake Paul has amassed 26.6 million Instagram followers, 17.8 million TikTok followers, and nearly 20.7 million YouTube subscribers. He started in content creation when monetization was in its infancy, and managed to amass almost two billion views making comedy videos on Vine (RIP), beginning around 2013.\n\nFast-forward a decade, and Paul's consistent work ethic has catapulted him from influencer to entrepreneur to professional boxer. He is fighting former UFC fighter and bare-knuckle-boxing champion Mike Perry in his eighth pro match on Saturday, and taking on Boxing Hall of Famer Mike Tyson on November 15, which will be streamed on Netflix.\n\nPaul, it seems, is no longer just about comedy and pranks.\n\n\"It's just very surreal and it feels like all my hard work is starting to pay off,\" Paul tells Entrepreneur over a video call. \"I'm very honored to be in the ring with Mike Tyson. After 12 to 15 years of knocking down the door of opportunity, I was able to open this door. So it just goes to show that you have to start with one step at a time and grow into things like these, that you can't even believe you're doing.\"\n\nWhen the Tyson fight was announced, Paul emerged as the favorite to win. But his response wasn't one of an untouchable heavyweight -- he's just happy to be here. And yes, he says he is scared to fight Tyson.\n\n\"Fear is always going to be there, you're always going to be scared,\" Paul said. \"I'm scared to fight Mike Tyson. I'm scared to fight Mike Perry. It's about being brave enough to have the courage to do it when the fear is never going away. You have to embrace it and let it fuel you versus let it stop you from maybe making the best decision of your life.\"\n\nStill, he hasn't been without controversy. Business Insider reports allegations of online scams, abusive behavior, and vandalism.\n\nHis videos filming protests during the pandemic in 2020 led to the FBI raiding his home in 2021 in connection to a looting incident at an Arizona shopping mall. Paul was charged with trespassing and unlawful assembly.\n\nFollowing an investigation, the U.S. Attorney's Office ruled that he would not face federal charges.\n\nAround the same time, Paul had tension with the mayor of Calabasas, California, when he threw a massive party during the pandemic, despite social distancing restrictions.\n\nDespite the setbacks, Paul didn't step away from the spotlight and took it as a learning lesson. Paul's net worth is now an estimated $34.3 million.\n\nPaul owns four businesses -- sportsbook app Betr, VC fund Antifund, sports promotion company Most Valuable Promotions -- and now his latest, a men's body care line, W, sold direct-to-consumer at Walmart, which launched in June.\n\n\"I started not knowing what anything was, I just learned a little every single day, accumulated knowledge, applied all my learnings, and worked harder than my peers,\" Paul said.\n\nPaul likens W products to \"a new, better version of Axe for millennials.\"\n\n\"These old legacy brands that we're going up against are companies owned by massive conglomerates. We're coming in with a new game plan, and a new way to market,\" Paul added. \"There's so much room to grow and to change things here and to innovate on a product that can connect with a younger audience of men, which is my audience.\"\n\nRelated: Ringside Tyson-Paul Fight VIP Tickets Selling for Millions\n\nPaul's marketing techniques are not for everyone (he was nearly attacked by a shark, and filmed a lie detector test on Instagram), but they feel authentic to who he is and his already hyper-online social media presence.\n\n\"I think people should be themselves. Authenticity is what's winning, show your failure, show your mistakes, tell your story,\" Paul said. \"The struggle is what people can relate to, and I think that's what's missing with a lot of entrepreneurs.\"\n\nPaul says when he was making videos on Vine as a teen a decade ago, he anticipated how big the influencer economy could be one day. He was right: A recent report from Emarketer projected that U.S. marketer spending on sponsored social-media content could rise 16% this year to $8.14 billion.\n\n\"[Back then], the numbers spoke for themselves,\" he said. \"We were Viners getting millions of views on our Vines and getting paid like $2,000 for a video, but a commercial slot on TV would get maybe 500,000 views, and they get paid $100,000 or $200,000.\"\n\nPaul said he knew eventually that numbers \"would be the most important thing,\" and that influencers and creators would become more valued. \"And that's becoming true,\" he added.\n\nPaul says his first paycheck was for $300, and he spent it on Christmas-edition LeBron James sneakers and a Diesel watch.\n\n\"You have to embrace it and let it fuel you versus let it stop you from maybe making the best decision of your life.\"\n\nTransitioning into the business world didn't come without a slew of haters, either.\n\n\"I [was] scared to put W into the world to see how people are going to receive it,\" he said.\n\nPaul says that he heard a quote years ago about entrepreneurs being the best at sweeping their mistakes under the rug, learning, and moving on, and he tries to remember that when things get tough.\n\n\"It hasn't been easy at all, it's difficult every single day still,\" Paul said.\n\nRelated: Jake Paul Reportedly Earned Sky-High Amount for Fight\n\nAnd he may just be fighting his old reputation for a while: After all, he knows the Internet is forever.\n\n\"I want people to look at me as an example of the American dream, of relentlessly pursuing my dreams for over a decade and never stopping when I fell flat on my face and persevering through all of those moments,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "entrepreneur.com", "dataType": "news", Speaking to Ariel Helwani on The MMA Hour, Bidarian admitted that the idea of an interfamily bout between the two brothers was floated to Netflix after Tyson was pulled through medical concerns.\n\nSpeaking about trying to make a Logan and Jake fight work, Bidarian explained on Wednesday: \"We said to Netflix, we could get the two of them to agree to do it on July 20th on Netflix. I think Netflix saw it as a phenomenal, massive event, with not enough run-up [time] to do it the right way.\"\n\nInstead of pushing for a bout between the two brothers, Netflix would instead opt to reserve their initial scheduled bout between Jake and Tyson, rescheduling for November 15. Eager to still compete this month, Jake instead worked a deal with DAZN to fight 14-8 UFC and BKFC star Perry come July 20.\n\nAnd while we could have seen Jake and Logan throw down in a mega-fight for the ages this weekend, Bidarian is confident that the fight will definitely take place at some point down the line. He added: \"They have the utmost love for each other, but there is a competitive nature between them, absolutely. This is an older brother, younger brother dynamic always, right? And I do believe you'll see that fight at some point. And there is not one ounce of wrestling in it. It is 100 percent real.\"\n\nJake Paul has accrued a coveted 9-1 boxing record since turning pro back in 2020 - beating former UFC stars like Ben Askren, Nate Diaz, Anderson Silva and Tyron Woodley twice. His only loss came to the hands of Tommy Fury - brother of Tyson Fury - in February last year via split decision.\n\nPerry, on the other hand, is currently riding a 5-0 win streak with bare-knuckle promotion BKFC, racking up wins over the likes of Eddie Alvarez and Luke Rockhold. He has also been involved in some of the bloodiest battles in UFC history, with wins over Paul Felder, Mickey Gall, Alex Reyes and Jake Ellenberger.\n\nLogan, meanwhile, has had a far less active boxing career, with just two pro bouts to his name over the years. He made his pro debut against YouTube star KSI in 2018, losing via split decision, before taking on Dillon Danis in October 2023 - where he would achieve a DQ victory after frustrating the Bellator star over the course of six rounds.\n\nDanis would attempt to get Paul in a guillotine before rushing the 29-year-old after the final bell had rang, leading to an all-out ring invasion as officials and cornermen tried to get the situation under control. Logan's most notable bout, however, would come in the form of a 2021 exhibition with 50-0 Floyd Mayweather Jr - going the distance with the boxing GOAT over eight rounds while holding his own.", {"uri": "8234810676", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "10:09:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T10:09:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T10:07:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/sport/11935902/jake-paul-sparring-mike-perry-fight/", "title": "I was there for Jake Paul's sparring with Perry... their fight won't last long", "body": "WHEN Jake Paul makes his boxing return against Mike Perry it will not be the first time the pair have shared the ring.\n\nThe two clash in Florida on Saturday - four years after their disputed sparring session in Miami.\n\nAt the time, Paul, 27, was being coached by former cruiserweight contender BJ Flores, who contacted Perry, 32, for sparring.\n\nAnd in an interview with The U.S. Sun, he recalled his memory of the five-round session between the now-opponents.\n\n\"Mike was very game and very tough. But I couldn't say I gave him a round though in professional scoring,\" Flores said.\n\n\"Jake was landing the harder shots and Jake was in control but Mike was game.\n\n\"It's gonna be a good fight early on, I'm telling you right now, but it's not gonna last too long.\n\n\"I can't see Mike being that aggressive and lasting. Jake has matured a lot as a fighter since then.\n\n\"He's been working nonstop. He's coming into his man years and man strength now.\n\n\"People don't realize how much ability he's got. who drew to Logan in their first meeting before emerging victorious in the professional ranks for the rematch - has since gone into business with the now-WWE star.\n\nYet the rivalry with Jake Paul has only festered following years of social media barbs, and everyone wants the pair to finally get it on.\n\nAs of yet, there has been no official fight date pencilled in, but KSI did call for a fight in December 2024.\n\nHowever, the American is planning to face Mike Tyson in November after the initial bout with the 58-year-old was postponed due to concerns over Tyson's health.\n\nOnce the fight was initially cancelled, Paul desperately tried to find a replacement.\n\nThis saw him publicly ask KSI to step in, only to be told by the Londonder that he had an alternatve fight arranged for August 31, where he will take part in the latest Misfits event.\n\nHe is set to take on Slim Albaher and Anthony Taylor in a 2 versus one bout.\n\nMeanwhile, Paul is set to face Mike Perry as a warm-up for Tyson.\n\nTherefore, should Paul beat Perry and the fight with Tyson goes ahead, we might not see this long-awaited clash until next year.\n\nOf course, Tyson's health has postponed the bout once and could again, so if that happens, KSI could get his wish for a clash with Paul at 185lbs in December.\n\nBut there are a lot of unknowns when it comes to Paul and KSI fighting anytime soon.\n\nBoxing promoter and Matchroom chairman, Eddie Hearn, has told Paul to forget about his fight wit Tyson and set up a clash against KSI.\n\nSpeaking to DAZN, he said: \"Jake Paul and KSI do huge numbers.\n\n\"In the UK, you're talking about one million buys plus. In the US, it will do a strong number, globally both guys have incredible followings in key territories. It's a huge fight.\n\n\"But one of the problems is both guys are quite young and both have big egos. Both guys have opinions about their value and their worth, and that's bigger than the other person.\n\n\"To make a fight like that will take both of them to really want that fight and come together and say, 'Regardless of whether I think I'm a little bit bigger than you, shall we just say it's 50/50 for all the money in the pot and let's make a fortune.'\n\n\"As you become older and more sensible, that's what fighters get to sometimes. They [initially] think it's 60/40 in their favour, but in the end, you're better off going 50/50.\n\n\"We're lucky that this fight is still big because Jake Paul lost to Tommy Fury and if he doesn't {"uri": "8234971329", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "12:38:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T12:38:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T12:37:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/boxing/jake-paul-next-fight-opponent-b2583019.html", "title": "The hidden side of Jake Paul", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\n\"Are we doing video?\" Jake Paul asks, half-aiming the question at me and half-directing it towards his representative on the Zoom call. \"Err, yeah?\" I reply. \"I don't usually upload the video from these sorts of chats, but...\"\n\nBut it would seem strange to interview one of the biggest screen presences of the last decade and not have him appear, well, on screen.\n\n'Biggest' replaces 'most popular' here, given the word 'popular' tends to imply widespread affection, and it's fair to say that Paul is more well-known than well-liked. Controversies have arisen at intervals since the American emerged on Vine in 2013, three years before his two-season stint on the Disney Channel series Bizaardvark. Paul, 27, has nevertheless only seen his profile grow in the decade since, with 20 million YouTube subscribers and 25m Instagram followers at the time of writing. Still, he does not identify as a YouTuber or influencer anymore; he's a professional boxer.\n\nIf his knockout win over former NBA star Nate Robinson in 2020 didn't convince you, or his knockouts of MMA stars Tyron Woodley and Ben Askren in 2021, or his decision win over UFC legend Anderson Silva in 2022, then he hoped his fight with Tommy Fury would have. Well, kind of; Paul would argue he doesn't care what you think at all, even after Fury outpointed him in February 2023.\n\nHe has since bounced back with a decision win over another UFC legend Nate Diaz and first-round knockouts of Andre August and Ryan Bourland. An intriguing, if controversial, fight against Mike Tyson was lined up for this weekend before the former boxing heavyweight champion of the world was forced to postpone until November due to a health scare - meaning professional MMA fighter/bare-knuckle boxer Mike Perry has stepped up instead.\n\nWhen I start our interview - conducted a week before the Fury fight - by asking what the biggest misconception about Jake Paul is, he takes a moment to think, before laughing: \"I think people... they don't think I'm a real person. And I think they judge me from my past a lot, versus looking at who I am today. I think, as humans, we naturally do that, so I get it. But yeah, I think that's it...\n\n\"And they compare me to my brother,\" he quickly adds, referring to Logan, 29, who has followed a similar path to his younger sibling. \"Whenever he does something wrong, I get in trouble for it. I would probably say that's the biggest thing.\"\n\nPaul has an almost unrivalled proclivity for, simply put, winding people up. It is one of the clearest explanations for how the American has secured bouts with some of the highest-profile names in combat sports en route to going 9-1, and it is how he secured his fight with Fury - half-brother of world heavyweight boxing champion Tyson - and then a clash with UFC icon Diaz.\n\nPaul, a lot of the time, is a troll, and some people genuinely detest him for it. When friends first heard that I had interviewed him, their reactions eclipsed any interest they had in the fact that I met Anthony Joshua for the first time on the same day. Love him or hate him - and you'd probably say you hate him - people care about Jake Paul.\n\n\"I think the smart people in the world see that I'm able to play chess in the entertainment industry and make really smart moves,\" the Ohio native explains. \"Then there's the sheep who are like, 'Argh, that kid! I saw he said this! Blah, blah, blah.' Like, I did that on purpose, to get you riled up. It's marketing at the end of the day.\"\n\nIt can be argued that the side of Paul that some find irritating is just a facade, and fairly obviously so. Why, then, are people so irked by what he says?\n\n\"I think because it's true,\" he suggests, a slight smirk splitting his lips. So when Paul says something mean about you, he believes it - even if he doesn't mean it. Like the incisive, inebriated insults that you withdraw when the alcohol has washed away.\n\n\"The deepest insults are the ones that you believe to be true within your own mind,\" Paul continues. \"Those are your insecurities. If I'm attacking these people's insecurities, they're gonna get all riled up, p****d off, bent out of shape.\"\n\nPaul, for his part, does not seem to take anything that anyone says about him remotely personally. \"When they say anything about me, I've dealt with all my insecurities as a man. I've looked myself in the mirror and gone through so many spiritual, healing journeys. You don't just all of a sudden not have insecurities, but I've dealt with mine. So, if someone brings them up, it's like... I don't care, because I love myself.\"\n\nHe hasn't always loved himself, though. When asked what motivates a young man who has already reaped such riches, like a reported $38m net worth, to spend so much of his time getting punched in the face, he starts, \"It's funny...\" before following up with reasoning that is anything but that. Still, he smiles as he says it: \"I need boxing. Boxing saved me. I was in a super dark place in my life.\n\n\"I lacked discipline, lacked routine, lacked community, lacked passion, lacked progress. Boxing gave me all of those things, and I loved punching people and getting punched! I love the pace of it, the strategy, everything behind it. It's an art. Then there's the build-up, the content, the press conferences, the outfits. All of it made me fall in love with boxing, to a point where I need boxing on a daily basis just to function. I love the sport, that's really what it is.\"\n\nAnd that's the thing: For all the criticism Paul used to get for not having fought a 'real boxer', he has always taken this endeavour seriously.\n\n\"It's the most intense thing you can imagine in your mind,\" the 27-year-old says of his training. \"I'm going to my limit every single day. It's a team of eight people, fully dedicated to making this operation work - from strength and conditioning coaches to stretch therapists to three boxing coaches who are watching my every single move. It's strategy, it's gameplan, it's film review, it's repetition - pounding it over and over again. I'm studying my opponent and training like a professional athlete, with state-of-the-art facilities. It's as serious as it gets, because my life's on the line, so I'm not gonna take that lightly. And I don't want to lose, and I have all the resources available to have the best team and things around me.\"\n\nBefore the fact, Paul's match-up with Fury in February 2023 felt like an endgame for the American; win or lose, he would have been able to dismiss jibes that he had not fought a professional boxer. But it was not the endgame that many had predicted; just six months on, Paul dropped and outpointed 38-year-old Diaz - an MMA fan favourite who achieved crossover fame by submitting Conor McGregor in 2016, and who left the UFC in September 2022. August and Bourland were then dispatched before Tyson was lined up, although that will ahve to wait until November. At this point, it is unclear what Paul's endgame will be.\n\nNevertheless, \"I think I'll always box, for sure,\" Paul insists. \"And I hope to be a boxing coach one day. I'm obviously already a promoter; I think I'll promote fights for the rest of my life,\" he says, referencing his significant work with champion Amanda Serrano, for whom he secured the first seven-figure payday in women's boxing history.\n\n\"This sport is now a part of my DNA forever,\" he concludes.\n\nTalking to Paul, rather than about him, you see glimpses of the \"real person\" that others don't believe exists. Yet it is largely down to Paul that people don't see the man behind the mocking.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Rob Manfred Net Worth: How much does Rob Manfred make a year as MLB comissioner?\n\nMike Perry, the mixed martial artist, has garnered a net worth of $1 million through his career, primarily competing as a welterweight in the UFC. Born in Flint, Michigan, in September 1991, Perry began his MMA journey in 2014, initially fighting as a lightweight before transitioning to the welterweight division. He made an impressive MMA debut with a win over Hector Tirado in September 2014, and by August 2016, he was making waves in the UFC with a victory over Hyun Gyu Lim.\n\nPerry's UFC career is marked by several standout performances. He earned the Performance of the Night awards for his wins over Jake Ellenberger in April 2017 and Alex Reyes in September 2017. Additionally, his bouts against Alex Oliveira in April 2019 and Vicente Luque in August 2019 were recognized as Fight of the Night. However, Perry also faced setbacks, including a loss to Tim Means in a catchweight bout in November 2020, bringing his record to 14-7.\n\nPerry's foray into the fighting world started young; he began training in boxing at just 11 years old. Despite encountering legal troubles and spending time in prison as a teenager, Perry turned his life around. He found work as a trainer at a local UFC gym, marking the beginning of his mixed martial arts career. His amateur fighting record was a respectable 8-3, paving the way for his professional endeavors.\n\nThroughout his UFC tenure, Perry fought and defeated notable fighters such as Alex Oliveira, Jake Ellenberger, and Paul Felder. His dedication and skill in the octagon earned him approximately $1.3 million from 15 UFC fights, averaging nearly $87,000 per fight. Perry's first-round knockout against Alex Reyes at UFC Fight Night 116 and his victory over Oliveira also brought in significant bonuses, with UFC President Dana White announcing an additional $50,000 for the latter.\n\nWhat's his salary with BKF?\n\nHowever, after his victory over Oliveira in April 2019, Perry experienced a series of losses, winning only one out of his next five fights. This challenging period led him to explore new opportunities, ultimately signing with the Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship (BKFC) in 2021.\n\nPerry's transition to bare-knuckle boxing proved lucrative; he reportedly earned $8 million contract with the BKFC. His undefeated status in BKFC highlights his continued success and solidifies his reputation in the sport.\n\nReflecting on his journey, Perry's resilience and determination shine through. His unwavering passion for combat sports has propelled him forward, and his move to the BKFC marks an exciting new chapter in his fighting legacy. {"uri": "8234182683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "21:47:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T21:47:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T21:46:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.boxingscene.com/jake-pauls-window-boxing-relevance-closing--184914", "title": "Is Jake Paul's window of boxing relevance closing?", "body": "Jake Paul came through the window that boxing provided by taking far too long to make the fights that fans wanted to see, but now that the sport is turning out a slew of anticipated bouts, how much longer will Paul remain relevant?\n\nThe YouTuber returns to the ring in Tampa, Florida, on Saturday, headlining his MVP Promotions card against former UFC and Bare Knuckle Fighting Championships slugger Mike Perry.\n\nThe bout fills in for Paul's postponed fight against 58-year-old former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson, which was moved to November at AT&T Stadium outside Dallas following Tyson being sidelined by an ulcer.\n\nPaul (9-1, 6 KOs) has made his name fighting guys who were known publicly, starting with a fellow YouTuber and moving on to an NBA player and a string of UFC fighters. But in his fight against former heavyweight champion Tyson Fury's younger brother, Tommy Fury, he lost, and has since posted some victories over underwhelming pros.\n\nSince Saudi Arabia's Turki Alalshikh and American promoters have moved so forcefully to make the major showdowns that previously seemed so difficult, the question looms about where this leaves Paul.\n\nIn the past year, boxing has given fans the undisputed welterweight title fight between Errol Spence Jr. and Terence Crawford, the undisputed heavyweight title fight between Fury and Oleksandr Usyk, and will stage the undisputed light heavyweight title fight between champions Dmitry Bivol and Artur Beterbiev, with Crawford headlining a stacked card in Los Angeles on Aug. 3.\n\nOn Thursday's episode of Pro Box TV's \"Deep Waters,\" analysts Chris Algieri and Paulie Malignaggi discussed how these boxing strides affect Paul.\n\n\"Jake is very smart - he created his own lane, signed fighters, created MVP Promotions. To me, Jake Paul is [this era's] 'Butterbean,'\" Algieri said of the former \"King of the Four-Rounders,\" a rotund heavyweight slugger whose novelty fights often landed on Top Rank pay-per-view cards a generation ago.\n\nAlgieri noted how Paul's rise, which included UFC fighters who specialized in wrestling, was \"carefully orchestrated.\n\n\"Jake is a good athlete who can punch and Jake's [improved] for real,\" Algieri said.\n\nStill, his fights are more novelty act than legitimate.\n\n\"It's still something positive for boxing because it shows when there's a fight, people want to watch it,\" Malignaggi said. \"When you were in school - junior high, high school - and there was a fistfight between two popular guys,\" students wanted to see it.\n\n\"This is what the YouTuber thing became. I'm not sure they know how to fight, but guys you know are fighting while guys who know how to fight aren't as popular as the popular guys. That's life. If popular guys get in a fight, people want to see it. It's high school all over again.\"\n\nMalignaggi admits the shelf life of the shtick seems to be nearing an expiration date.\n\n\"In some ways, you think, 'It had it's time ...'\" he said.\n\nThe analysts said Paul deserves serious props for supporting women's boxing, with titleholder Amanda Serrano on Saturday's card and heading to a rematch with undisputed champion Katie Taylor on the November card. Malignaggi calls lightweight prospect Ashton Sylve's Saturday bout against Lucas Bahdi as the best fight on the slate.\n\n\"That's how you make new fans of the sport,\" Malignaggi said.\n\nYet Algieri said he doesn't believe the Paul-Tyson fight will happen, due to Tyson's health issues, and he's not sold on the merits of cruiserweight Paul meeting the far lighter Perry on Saturday.\n\n\"This is boxing - bigger gloves, bigger guy,\" Algieri said.\n\nPaul once dreamed of fighting Saul \"Canelo\" Alvarez, but the 34-year-old undisputed super middleweight champion is in the process of making a fight, followed perhaps by showdowns with Crawford and a nine-figure meeting against unbeaten David Benavidez.", "source": {"uri": "boxingscene.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "BoxingScene.com"},
